description: This is how you know this is a good pace: Every time I come here, I wonder why other food courts across the country are not like this. What's not to like about authentic Poke, giant kimbop, and Beard Papas green tea cream puff?!  Sure, I may have Asian food bias but still, when a food court is not just all about the Sbarros, Cinnabon, and Panda Express, it's definitely refreshing. . With plenty of seating and "exotic" food options, this place never disappoints.
author: George W.

description: One of the better food courts with several good choices. Conveniently located right by the BART entrance.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Not a single garbage can?  What the f?  I'm sorry to start my review this way but I have two kids and we have garbage.  There wasn't a single garbage can to be found.

I think you just leave your trash on a random table and someone is hired to come around and pick it up.  These said cleaning people walk around with giant carts for picking up the garbage and the random plates and they separate it all to be thrown away or recycled.  These carts are pretty big and they do not care if they are in the way of moving people traffic at all.

Another thing about this food hub, there really isn't that much to choose from.  We walked around twice and finally decided on the lobster place but we really didn't even want that.

I think Ill go exploring other options when we visit again.
author: Ivy R.

description:
No frills food court at westfield center in sfo. Lots of choices from pastas, steaks, japanese, curries etc...

I had the 2 item combo of beef rendang and lemon grass chicken...you het a bowl.with generous serving of beef chunks in malaysian curry and a large piece.of chicken ...forgot to take a pict as i was hungry...for a guy..i couldnt even finish all..so ordered a side.of rice and shared with my wife...such good value for $. Kids had the pasta and chiecken terriyaki on rice....all were tasty and portions were big. 

Happy eating!!
author: Jon L.

description:
Some of the places are OK and others have really become bad due to recent changes. Now that the whole food court switched from actual silverware to plastic knives and forks eating at some locations makes it really difficult. Have you ever tried to eat a steak with plastic utensils? 

They replaced the glassware to plastic cups too. So I guess cut the staffing to less than half. Less than half means fewer people to clean the tables and wipe things clean.
author: M C.

description:
Okay..so you're in the City... on a Friday or Saturday night... and you don't have dinner reservations. You and your date or group can't decide if you want steak, pasta, Thai food, vegan, Mongolian barbecue, Brazilian, puff pastries, American, or a fancy grocery buffet... Well, the Westfield Food Court is the place to go. This is not your ordinary food court. There is ample comfortable seating amidst barriers and plants that make the seating options more intimate, workers with caddies that go through and clean up vacant tables, and crappy wi-fi--so you will be forced to enjoy the company your with or people watch. 

Affordable, convenient, and no reservations needed. Definitely my kind of place.
author: Tashara H.

description:
We're not in the suburbs and usually got better things to do than hanging out at the mall but if there is some shopping that needs to be done, Westfield SF is a great place to do so.

Make sure to visit the food court - great variety of food counters (Korean BBQ, Sushi, Burger, Sandwiches, Mexican, Thai, Italian...). I tried out the Thai food over there as well as the Mexican - both decent choices.

For "Andale", the Mexican counter: sure, you'll get better and more authentic food in the Mission, and they should have said somewhere that the burrito they serve is actually a "wet burrito". But nevertheless, decent and filling food.
author: Sebastian F.

description: Note: this is not a review of any of the restaurants, just the food court in general.  Due to traffic, we were late getting to the city for our pre-play dinner.  In this case, the food court was perfect.  It's right across the street from the Powell Bart and has a variety of restaurants.  It was great, because now we really couldn't decide on something we both wanted.  It's a bit rambling, so don't think the restaurants are only what you can see - go around the next corner.  They have a good selection: Buckhorn Grill, vegan, SF Soup Co, Panda, sandwiches, Chipotle, ice cream, etc.  We were there about 6:00 on a Tuesday, and there was plenty of seating.  Tables were fairly clean and there is wi-fi available.
author: Lydia C.

description:
It's a food court, for sure.  But it's a food court with a huge selection that will please everyone in your group; whether they are craving sushi, steak, mac and cheese, or veggie entrees.  This is one of the cheapest places to get a meal in the City  My daughter and I have been here many times and usually manage to get the both of us full for under $20!

Crowded on the weekends with both tourists and locals, the food emporium has a large enough seating area that you can almost always find a table.    It's pretty clean most of the time, especially when you consider the high foot traffic and its' proximity to BART.  

If you don't want to sit down and eat, a good choice is Bristol Farms market, which has a great selection of healthier foods and prepared dishes, such as pizza and sandwiches.  Very fairly priced for SF.

My favorite places: Pasta Moto (great pizza, spaghetti, roast veggies, and salads plus specialty items)  Buckhorn Grill (try the tri-tip salad for lunch- awesome and filling.)
author: Tammy D.

description:
This shopping center has great shops & food restaurants, I can just recommend it 

It's on a big shopping street, you can't not see it
author: Franzi S.

description: Super cool shopping center! Very unique and different from all of there other shopping centers I have been to over the years. Got tons of different levels to go to and some stores I haven't seen or been to before. They are even setting up the Christina's decorations already.
author: Magz K.

description:
Absolutely average. Nothing different than any food emporium I've seen all over the united states. Yeah - so it is big. But it is big with average places to eat. I would have liked to have seen something different than "everything else" - just doubled or tripled because of size...

but not so much.
author: Dan D.

description:
I love lobster. But who ever came up with this, and again I say " l Iove lobster", but don't eat here. If you don't execute lobster right, don't serve it to the public....The Lobster sandwich spot in the Westfield. 

The sandwich was so tiny. The roll was miniature. the $16 it cost pays for the 1/2 cup of lobster meat shoved in the small roll. Don't know who their lobster purveyor is, they need to switch that up! Go back east, these sandwiches are normal size sandwiches. I have had larger lobster rolls in New England than this franchise Lobster chain. 

Today experience: Most of my lobster was rubbery and stringy. I believe the lobster pieces come in a cry-o-vac bag, the meat was overcooked. The Lobster Mac and cheese had no flavor, the sauce was oily and not cheesy at all. All together=$30 disappointment. Don't believe the hype of this place.
author: Kitty L.

description:
I go to the Westfield Mall one or two times a week. Unfortunately, the basement food court is just average. Recently, two of the food venues have closed. Of course, they needed to close because they were serving crappy food. I expect "Lobster Me" will be next to close up.

It would be nice to see some classier food venues downstairs. I'd love to see an In-N- Out  Burger there. They'd probably put every other food venue in the court out of business, lol. 

As it stands now, Sarabol and Buckhorn will be the only two remaining when the smoke clears.
author: Anthony W.

description: I love this mall. This is co. Information from a guy who's used to going to hilltop mall growing up so yeah there's my comparison. The only problem for me as a male is and not surprisingly the mall is catered majority towards women but hey the food selection is pretty good
author: Leel W.

description:
I remember when the food court here was just the Nordstrom side of the mall. Ever since the Bloomingdale's side opened, the food court has gotten more and more varied. I do love that as I adore having options. Working downtown, I make the occasional stop here to run errands and grab lunch.

On the Nordstrom side, I've tried both Ajisen ramen and Napoleon macarons. Ajisen is a good option for quick ramen. Not as good as some of the ramen shops in the area, but if I don't want to wait forever for a table, Ajisen fulfills that ramen craving. Napoleon's macarons have great flavor, but I found them lacking in texture. More soft and cakey instead of having a slight chew.

On the Bloomingdale's side, I've actually tried more restaurants than places in the food court. Bristol farms is a nice option when you just want a variety of hot food. Kind of like a buffet. I've been known to grab a mishmosh of things (such as pizza, poki, etc) and bring them home for dinner. Recently, I tried Lobster me. Though it underwhelmed me, I was happy there was a lobster option in the mall.

There are so many restaurants in the food court. I'm surprised I haven't tried more places. After writing this review, I think I may make more trips to the Food Emporium.
author: Elena N.

description:
Food Emporium! That's just about right. 

I don't think any other mall can claim to have a full-scale supermarket in its food court. Yeah, Westfield SF is that cool. 

Spanning all food groups and personal preferences, if you can't find something to munch on here, well then you just aren't even trying. 

-Soup, sammies, salads
-Sushi
-All veg
- Fast foody Asian (aka the dark ages of mall food courts with only super dry chicken....jk)
- (myfave) DavidsTea slightly off center
-Dessert - options! Cupcakes, chocolate, and ice cream galore
-Bristol Farms (full-scale supermarket)

My brain hurts from trying to remember all the options. Did that answer the question for all the things i missed?

In fact, the food court probably offers more variety than the actual mall. Shopping? Meh. Food shopping? Okay!
author: Libby J.

description:
You're not in San Francisco to go to the mall. But sometimes you need some shopping to be done, and this place has a lot of stores. Also, it's sometimes nice to be in a modern environment in a very "classically styled" city, and this fits the bill.

Lots of options here, bigger than your standard mall food court. Multicultural too, which you don't get everywhere.

You could do worse.
author: Sean B.

description:
I love this mall simply because it is THE center mall for San Francisco, where you can enjoy walking around, shopping, eating at the best mall food court, meet up easily with friends or family and basically enjoy a great day to hangout!

I feel like you can find anything here - from clothing, shoes, accessories, name brands, furnishings and more!  This Westfield mall has everything - even coffee and a food market to keep you energized and productive if you are going to be here for the entire day, literally!

On top of that, the top level of this grand mall is elaborate with its intricate rooftop architecture as well as themed celebratory events - such as holidays when you can just feel the warmth and festivity!

This mall is and will be a classic place for entertainment and a delight for a shopping experience in San Francisco!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I cannot find where to voice a proper complaint to Westfield itself so I'll share here. I saw a woman that worked at the Charley's subs come out of the bathroom stall, still buttoning her pants, with her apron on, fixed her hair and left without washing her hands D: 

Ew.
author: Antoinette J.

description:
Located at the concourse level is the Westfield San Francisco Food Centre Food Emporium.  There's a large selection of food choices ranging from Korean, Japanese, Chinese, American, Thai, Mediterranean, Brazilian, Italian, sandwiches, soups, juices, pretzels, coffees and teas, and desserts, such as cupcakes and cream puffs.  You can also get hot food as Bristol Farms.

There is a large seating section in the center where you can park and enjoy your food. During the peak hours of lunch and dinner, it can be a challenge to get a table. There's free w-fi too.

A good pit stop for a food break while shopping in the San Francisco Centre or the area.
author: Al L.

description: Surprisingly, there are quite a few good selections for dinner and dessert.  My favorites include black bean noodles at Sorabol, Beard Papa cream puffs, and honey frozen yogurt at Yoppi.
author: Jenny L.

description: Wow...if malls near me had these type of food options then I would go to the mall more often. Pasta, lobster rolls and Brasil grill...plus numerous other options. The food court area is rather clean too - I was bringing a tray in when the nicest guy takes it from me with a smile.
author: Mikhail H.

description:
To be honest, if it wasn't for Loving Hut being located here, I'd probably never eat here.

I've tried a bunch of places here, and they are all just "ok."

I mean, I get it. It's a "Food Emporium." They have more classier fast-casual food. No McD's, Chipotle, Burger King, or Taco Bell here.

Instead, I bought a burger from "Burger Bistro" that charged me $10 and the quality was dry and full of iceberg lettuce.
I bought a burrito from that fancy Mexican place, and it was bland.
I bought Thai from that Thai place with the super long line, but it was oily.

So yes, "Emporium" is a nice word, but it's still mediocre quality.
Except Loving Hut. Their food tastes amazing every single time. I may be biased because I'm vegan, but I see a lot of meat eaters buying food from here and their eyes kinda light up as they're surprised at how good the quality is.

There seems to be a lot of seating, and it really should be. But if you come here between 12-1pm, good luck. Not a table in sight.

It's also a nice touch for the workers to go around and bus/wipe down tables.

For a tourist, it must be a breath of fresh air to have a group of friends and family who are hungry and don't have time/money/patience for a full service restaurant. That way, there's an option for everyone in the group and it's quick and affordable.
author: Lanie L.

description: We visited Westfield Mall in SF and dined at Buckhorn Grill for a quick lunch last Sunday. Regardless about the foods, the charges automatically included an3% S/F EMP MADATE without permission. We could have refused the charge but we chose not since this would be our the last visit.
author: Richard L.

description:
Westfield doesn't just have many "name" merchants., nevertheless, food quality here is superior to most courts. any one can find something they like. no need to dine in only one eatery

favs:
-beard papa cream puffs
-Ajisen amen
-vegan hut
-seafood place, nice fish & chip
-Bristol bay
-Chipotle, fallback if i can't decide
-out the door? never went
-M. Y. China" ? never went
-japanese snacks. interesting, didn't stay long
-Sorabol korean cuisine.
-froyo, gelato, artisan coffees nearby.

drawback:
-lack of seating during peak hours in the food court.
author: Victor G.

description:
This is an ever changing place. It seems that every time I walk through the bottom level of the Westfield Center, usually on my way to the Powell BART station, something is new here. 

Lots of choices, though, no matter what you might want to eat. I highly recommend this food court, at the far east end of the mall, when you are with a group of people who cannot make up their minds as to what to eat. Everyone will find something to make them happy.
author: Delaine Z.

description: My hotel was next to Westfield Mall (Hotel Zetta San Francisco). I came to Westfield San Francisco Centre Food Emporium numerous times during my stay in San Francisco. I'm not a big food court fan but Westfield San Francisco Centre Food Emporium is the exception.This food court has a variety of food options for customers. You will find fast food to quality meals. There are desserts options as well like Beard Papa's. The dining area is huge with plenty of seats (well maintained). Westfield San Francisco Centre Food Emporiumis a good place to fulfill your hunger in Union Square. I give Westfield San Francisco Centre Food Emporium a 4.5 rating.
author: Dominic B.

description:
I'll start off by saying that the 5 stars are not for the food. Most of the food is 3-3.5 stars and simply good for mall food. But the 5 stars are for the huge variety, the ease of eating here, the simplicity it might provide for groups of tourists needing an inexpensive meal in an expensive city, and for overall nice ambiance. This is not your typical food court. 

I ordered the taco plate from the mexican restaurant and a draft Pyramid Beer. The food was tasty and almost too much for me to eat. The tacos were loaded with meat, guacamole($1 extra), mexican cream, salsa, lettuce, and cheese. The pork was flavorable, the chicken not quite as much. Total for the beer and meal was ~$17

My wife had some kind of soy nuggets and sweet potato fries from a vegetairan place and said it was delicious. It was somewhere around $7-8.

I believe there were about 15 different food stands. If I were to return, I'd try Buckhorn or the lobster place. 

I liked it here and if you are in a group with a variety of tastes and don't want to break the bank, I really recommend this location.
author: John G.

description:
This is one of the biggest malls I've ever been to. I seriously can't tell where it ends, lol. It all connects.

I really like that sushi place that's in the food court though. There's so many restaurants in there, all different types of food.

There are a lot of stores to shop as well. I'm usually distracted by all the food so I haven't really bought anything else, lol.
author: Yee W.

description:
Coriander Thai has decided to up the prices they charge at registers without updating the prices they show their customers. 

As soon as you get through the register and your meal is magically bumped up a few dollars they pull the "next person please" and bank on heavy lunch traffic to keep people from noticing. 

Sketchy practice of secretly bumping prices means you end up paying $13-$14 for you-pick-a-scoop meal without a drink. 

If you're paying Caviar/Fastbite or Bento delivery prices you'd may as well get the food quality, value and convenience of delivery. 

If you're in a hurry and need a tasty lunch at the Westfield food court you're better off hitting the Korean spot which has just as many options and better business practices.
author: Lisa M.

description:
This review is for Westfield's food court, located on the lower level of the mall (floor LC).  It's nice, convenient, and very popular.  The food is decent, the restaurant selection is good, and the dining area has a cool, stylish design.  It's one of the nicer mall food courts I've been to in the States.  There's also free Wi-Fi, which works OK.

The only real downside I see to this food court is its small space.  It's often cramped and crowded with tiny, packed tables and long lines at many of the restaurants.  Sometimes, you're lucky to find an open seat.  Then again, it's not like the mall has much room to work with.

Some highlights include:

Kichi Grill - Japanese soba noodles, gyoza potstickers, sushi rolls
Loving Hut - vegan food
Godiva Chocolatier Express - picturesque stand
Buckhorn Grill - delicious tri-tip steak, sandwiches, salads
Sorabol - fast casual Korean BBQ, noodle soups
Amoura - Mediterranean shawarmas, falafels, gyros
Coriander - Thai food
Cako - cupcakes

There are a few more restaurants located on the other end of the floor including chains like Sarku, Chipotle, and Panda Express, and Ajisen Ramen from Japan.  I think it's hard to go wrong with most of the restaurants.

One thing about this food court which makes it different from other food courts is you don't have to clear your table when you're finished eating.  Food court staff promptly clear and clean tables once customers are done.

Overall, Westfield's food court is another nice American mall food court.  I give it 3.5 stars rounded up to 4 because of its unique chic and modern look.  If you don't mind crowds, it's a neat place to check out.
author: Daniel B.

description: It's so overwhelming! So many food choices. Good stop by if you're shopping around the union square area with a group of indecisive people. Everyone can go pick what they want.
author: Cindy H.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of malls, particularly the food courts with their Sbarros, Panda Express, and Great Steak and Potato Companies. Westfield does the food court right with a small dose of bigger chains (they do have a Panda) and plenty of smaller, more unique places like Loving Hut Vegan Cafe. It's also well maintained; clean and brightly lit. 

I'm afraid to let the secret out, but if you're looking for food while attending a conference at Moscone, this place can't be beat. It's close enough to duck out and back in a hour, but far enough to skirt the long lines in the immediate vicinity; even at huge conferences. It's packed with enough variety that you could return multiple days in a row and not eat the same thing. 

Well done Westfield, well done.
author: Mary T.

description: What a joke.  They do not have the contact number for Wood Stop, a kiosk vendor located in the mall.  This vendor does not have a website and no other way to reach them.  It seems like in the modern world this type of thing is mandatory to be a vendor at a major shopping center.  As the person who I spoke to on the phone at Westfield said "we are waiting for them to provide contact info".  Pretty lame.  Pretty shady.
author: Moody G.

description:
Phenomenal food court! It has a variety of foods to choose from! There's Mediterranean, Korean, Japanese, Chinese, Thai, American, etc!! As big as the food court seating area is, it can be difficult to find a seat since this place can get super busy & crowded! 
I went to Sorabol to get the 2-item combo (beef short rib/galbi) which came with rice, kimchi, broccoli & japchae, totaling $12.95 (w/o tax). 
I ordered the tofu Stew on the side, which although tasted great, was too pricy ($5/small cup). 
However, from what I ordered, the food was phenomenal. It was surprisingly comparable to other regular Korean restaurants.  Of course since it was a food court vendor, there were no banchans, and the tofu Stew was way overpriced for its portion. It was about $20 total for my meal. 
At this price, I would have rather just gone to an actual Korean restaurant and gotten the extra perks (banchans, bigger portions).
However, the food emporium is still a great place to stop by if you are in the area, so I do recommend checking this place out. The atmosphere is very lively and food selection is fantastic!
author: Hu L.

description: Westfield San Francisco's Food Emporium is delicious!! One of the nicest food courts I have ever been to like other Westfield food courts! Has high quality food, different cuisines, artesian pastries, gelato, crepes, and more! There's a Häagen-Dazs next to it, a farmer's market grocery store right across from it! They even have a Godiva chocolate bar! Such a great food court with something for everyone! :)
author: Busayo O.

description:
Corriander:

Sweet Thai Basil Chicken. 

Nuff said.
author: Jay C.

description:
This is like the Creme de la Creme of shopping mall Food Courts. Perfect for San Francisco, where shoppers usually consider themselves foodies, locals and tourists alike. This is a good place to bring your cousin from Lodi and impress her with SF's city cool style, even in food courts! Of course, it is not hard to impress her if all she is used to is shopping in Stockton or Tracy. 

This is on the concourse level of the Westfield Mall, or as most people know it, the Nordstrom Mall. Westfield Mall's are all over the world, and it is actually a huge Australian outfit that owns Westfield Valley Fair in San Jose, Westfield in Culver City, and a bunch more in the US, Australia, the UK, and other hotspots. 

Calling it the Food Emporium is a bit of an homage to the old Emporium, the 'Big E", which for decades was a downtown SF department store fixture, and a regional chain with stores on the SF Peninsula. It was afflliated with the sister chains of Capwell's in the east bay, Weinstock's in Sacramento, and Broadway's in SoCal. The Big E in San Francisco had it's famous Dome, and basement specials, and had a Notions department. The entire chain was bought out and by Federated I think, and maybe parts were sold off to Macy's. 

I digress, but the name Emporium has a soft spot in many old San Franciscans' heart and wallet. So The Food Emporium name provides either some instant comfort, or confusion to the Westfield Mall shopper, depending on their senility. 

The Big E was never this nice. The Food Emporium is nothing like your standard Food Court. It is closer to Macy's Cellar, but with many different food concessions. The decor is upscale, to match that unique circular Escalator this mall is known for, which really impresses those relatives from Lodi, or Manteca, or Modesto. 

There are modern chandeliers, colorful decor, rich textures and better than Ikea furniture in the Food Emporium. And you can find better than Sbarro's TCBY, Annie's Pretzel's, and Cinnabon food sources here. Like Pete's Coffee (better than Starbucks) and Melt, for Gelato and Crepes, and many more lunch and dinner eateries. 

So when in-laws from the great San Joaquin Valley come into town to visit, wow them with shopping and the upscale escalator in the Westfield Mall, and impress them with the fancy Food Emporium, and you will avoid having to take them to an expensive, real SF restaurant.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
Really good selection for a food court! I'm talking thai, wraps, soups, burgers, burritos, different kinds of sweets, and stuff I'm sure I didn't even notice.

I'm used to getting variety at a food court, but usually at crappy chains- think Taco Bell-style food. The selection of restaurants here is more focused on quality, and if you don't happen to find exactly what you want, or if what you want is a little more healthy- BAM! Bristol Farms is adjacent to the food court and has everything to meet those needs, too.

And the food court isn't the only food options for this mall, either- there are a lot of sit-down restaurants sprinkled around, too, including M.Y. China right down the hall.
author: Stefany V.

description: If you want something decent to good to eat fast & cheap, this is the place.  The only thing I do not like is there are really not many open seating.  There are only a few seats for each vendor and even if it's open, you will not be able to sit there unless you buy their food.
author: Judy S.

description:
It blows my mind that this is a FOOD COURT IN A MALL.

Coming from the East Bay, I'm used to pieces of shit such as New Park Mall, Southland, or the slightly better but still awful Great Mall. As a major foodie stepping into Westfield's Food Emporium, it's like stepping into heaven on Earth.

Location:
It's inside Westfield Shopping Centre on the lower floor. It's pretty huge so you can't miss it.

Variety:
There aren't stupid Hot Dog on a Stick takeaways here. The food here is GOOD. You have...

~ Steaks
~ Korean BBQ
~ Japanese
~ Vegetarian/Vegan
~ Desserts
~ Italian

and anything else your little food-craving self can dream of. Even if you're one of the world's most pickiest eaters like me, you're guaranteed to find a delicious spot to dig in.

My recommendations:
~ Buckhorn Grill for some delicious medium-rare tri-tip steaks.
~ Melt for some of the best crepes you'll ever have.
~ Beard Papa's for some yummy and simple cream puffs.

NOTES:
~ One downside of this food court is that it's extremely popular so beware. If you're with a large group, it could be difficult to nab seats.
author: Clarissa Y.

description: Japanese cuisine is of course very tasty and the bar his high for any establishment. Kichi Grill gets a star for location(in the mall downtown),accessibility,customer service,time to for food all add up to a plus. But what about the food? I ordered the grill rice salmon bowl-wow! The rice was super delicious,i had only expected average. the vegetables perfectly cooked,and the salmon grilled to perfection. It was moist,tender,and tasty. I can't wait to try some more of their dishes.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
The edible variety that exists inside this MALL of all places serves up some tasty bites.  The selection ranges from over-priced to over-priced with quality food to back it up.  Bristol Farms has a nice selection if you only shop at Whole Foods and need some change in your daily routine.  The food is made fresh daily and options are bountiful. Corriandor Thai has to serve some of the best take-out available, while burger joints and burritos lie just footsteps away.

Grab a spoonful of gelato on your way out and make sure to hit up the chocolate kiosk for a small sample that will keep you coming back for more.
author: Kevin J.

description:
I love the food court for the variety of choices. 

This review received a 1 star rating for safety and security issue.  My bag was stolen here.

Yesterday, while sitting on a bar stool in the food court, at the counter to the right of restaurant Andale, my computer bag was stolen. I hung my bag on the stool while eating. I was lucky to note a movement of my chair,  turned around, noted my bag was gone. 

Hopped off the bar stool immediately and saw a woman walking off with my bag.  I ran after her and grabbed my bag back. She acted surprised, dropped my bag and walked away. This incident stunned me and others who were sharing the counter with me.

I reported the incident to the Westfield security.  Lady next to me who worked at one of the stores in the mall, said customers go their phone stolen while they put them on the counter to look at merchandise, thief just cased the place, ran in grab the phone and ran out. 

Please be very careful with purses, bags, phones while eating in that food court.
author: Linh H.

description: Great mall. I like the food court in here. There is a good variety of choices, many of them are a bit upscale for a food court. Seating can be tricky, but its do-able. There is also a wide variety of shopping choices. It is pretty clean and doesn't smell too terrible (in SF this is always a factor to consider).
author: Jenny M.

description:
I must say, I do quite enjoy the Westfield Mall here in downtown San Francisco. Located right above the Powell Street BART Station. It's very easy to get to!

Plan to spend at least a few hours here, especially if you like shopping!
author: Charles K.

description:
i like the Thai fast food place here.
I forget the name, but it has been there for years now.
For mall food, it's excellent.
Last time I was in SFO, I ate at the Thai place three nights in a row; that's how much I like it.
author: Harry M.

description:
Good food options packed into a convenient location right under the mall.

Growing up in the bay area, I was kind of spoiled until I went out of state. There aren't a lot of malls with food options as good as the ones here.
author: Patrick T.

description:
As far as mall food go this place is pretty good. Prices are fairly high for the amount of food given. Probably varies from vendor to vendor. Try the Thai place and the pasta and buckhorn. 

There is one place though you need to stay away from.  Andale!  Ordered the nachos. It sounded good on the menu but boy was it far from it. The guacamole and the sour creme was good as well as the salsa but the cheese, chips and meat was horrible. The meat, we got the steak was burnt, hard and dry. The cheese was melted together, not liquid like. Since they put it in the oven, the chips were burnt. I think someone forgot about it. Believe me the chef doesn't really know nachos. For 10.75, go somewhere else. Should have take a picture and returned it. Garbage.
author: Christian S.

description: Great food selection but generally an unpleasant dining experience. Vagrants taking food scraps from tables. Panhandlers begging  4 money. Filthiest public bathroom in California.
author: scott h.

description:
After arriving hungover and hungry, my friend picked me up from SFO and immediately said, "lets go eat at Westfield food court." 

I said: "Food court? I don't want no cheap taco bell or McDonalds....I can get that in Vegas!"

And he said, "Trust me!"

So who was I to complain...I was the tourist!

He. Did. Not. Let. Me. Down!


This place is a gourmet food court on acid!
- Fancy Korean bbq, like that of restaurants in Hawaii. 
- Beard Papa's cream puffs, which I've only seen in Hawaii and Japan. 
- They even have a grocery store in there called Bristol Farms.


Those workers in the mall and Downtown SF are eating like kings and queens with a food court like this in the area!
author: Laurie V.

description:
I don't know what it is but something about food courts just makes me hungry. You know you aren't here for quality, you are here for affordability, choice and costco style free samples on toothpicks. 

This food court has a lot of unique qualities.
- Takes up pretty much all of the bottom level of one of the most unique Westfield malls. 
- Prime location right off market street
- Bart has an entrance to it
- Super market in a food court, not sure who does their grocery shopping here but I would be interested to see that demographic

Some of my favorite vendors:
- Sarku Japan
- Ajisen Ramen
- Buckhorn Grill
- Pretzels (Wetzels or Annies)
author: Luke O.

description: There are so many choices at this place that it's no wonder that so many of my co-workers eat here often.  Corriander is my favorite - green chicken curry and noodles.  Bristol Farms has a great deal on Monday's for a prime rib or carved turkey sandwich.  Buckhorn Grill has huge salads.  The Korean and vegan place both have great soups for a cold day.  The only one I don't recommend is the mexican place.  Great food court.  Just avoid at lunch on days there is a big conference in the area.
author: Amanda K.

description: Visited this food court for the first time and was impressed.  I had Andale Mexican food. I had the Andale Burrito.  Excellent! It was very fresh and the steak was so tender!  I wish they had this restaurant in the South Bay!
author: Erika P.

description: Andales is the bomb! Everything I tried on the menu was very good and full of flavor. I really like the presentation of the food. I would choose Andeles over Chipotle anyday. One of my favorite places to eat. The cooks seem to care about how the food actualy looks and taste. Thumbs up. Shout out to Mercedes your cool! And Im not just saying that cause your name is the same as a luxury car lol Thanks for serving me.
author: Todd M.

description: They have a huge variety of cuisine for every whim. Love to splurge and all in a few steps.
author: Tina L.

description:
This is a nice food court, lots of options....with some relatively "high end/fancy" options.  It's also right next to a Bristol farm so you can get food from their salad/hot foods bar too.  

Reminds me of the food court at Century City mall
author: Ben Y.

description:
NICEEEEEE food court.  One of the better ones that i've been in.  Their food court is huge.  It almost takes up the whole floor.  There are almost 30 individual booths? Stalls? that are in this food court.

There's something for everyone.  Even you picky people.

It took us about 10 minutes to walk around the whole food court in order to see everything they had to offer... before finally deciding on what we wanted.

The Thai food from Coriander Gourmet Thai was good.  Lots of variety in their menu.
http://www.yelp.com/biz/coriander-gourmet-thai-san-francisco

Frank M. went with Buckhorn Grill and LOooOoveeedd the plate he ordered.  Sorry Hun, they're only located in N. Cali. :(
http://www.yelp.com/biz/buckhorn-grill-san-francisco-2

I went with Kichi Grill and got their two item combo.  I liked it! Although.. yes.. this place would qualify as typical mall food. :P
http://www.yelp.com/biz/kichi-grill-san-francisco
author: Emily S.

description: Out of all the years I've eaten here I felt compelled to write a review now because I experienced a less-than good lunch here today. I started patronizing this location since it's opening in the food court at the glorious Westfield Mall. It used to be a destination lunch spot for me because of the huge quantity of food, and the good quality. Well, the quality has certainly declined over the past several months but today really grossed me out. I had the Panang Beef Curry with white rice and Pad Thai. The beef was cubed and tasted old and dry. The curry sauce was ok but missing that distinctly nutty taste I look forward to with panang. The pad thai was gross. The sauce was obviously burned as it tasted bitter and the noodles were extra chewy. Yum, just what I wanted on my lunch hour -- old beef and rubber bands. I won't be returning to this establishment.
author: Shannon B.

description:
Why I can see people liking this place:

-- the variety of nouveau stands: they have aren't your typical mall food stands (although I don't see anything wrong with a Great Steak and Fry once in awhile).
-- the people watching is more fun out here

Why I don't get it:

-- why it gets really crowded: does everyone who works in the mall eat here?
-- why the samples from Buckhorn Grill taste better than the lunch I just bought?
-- why this place is so highly reviewed?


Conclusion:

It's a food court folks.  I don't care how hard you try to dress it up.  At best the food is good but when you take into account how much you've paid for it, then it becomes a rip off.  For the price you're paying, you could go to an actually restaurant.
author: Dan B.

description:
My Plate:  Korean BBQ 
Weff's Plate:  Nutella Crepe 
CA's Plate:  Tri-Tip & a smoothie
Jammer's Plate:  Shrimp Tacos & a Negro Modela     

...and that's what I love about this place:  Everyone's really happy 'cause everyone is eating exactly what they want.  In fact, the only conflict here is between the side of me that wants Korean BBQ and the side that wants a gigantic fajita salad.    

As food courts go, this is as good as they get.  It's an excellent place to watch people, watch food, and watch people eating food.  

You're in the City, you're well fed, and multiple floors of shopping await you.  Be still my beating heart.  I love this place.
author: Tracey A.

description:
It's a food court but it's still a great place to stop for a meal.  Great selection, good food, nice dining area, but loud and crowded during peak hours.  

Is it better than going to a restaurant?  Hell no, but it's a FOOD COURT so stop complaining.  Is this the best food court I've seen?  Probably, so 5 stars is what I'm giving it and you'll accept it and like it.
author: Mark J.

description:
This is an amazing food court~~ I have eaten here many times, and tried the yummy gelato, ate the Thai food, and even one day ordered a rip-off salad : /  They have a Peet's coffee which brews really fresh coffee!  (according to my Aunt; as we got coffee later in the day at another Peet's location and she was disappointed at the UN-FRESHNESS).

Surprisingly, well maybe not so surprisingly because this "Food Emporium" is so busy.  I was scanning the seating area for wall chargers but didn't find any.  If they did have some, it'd turn into some sort of coffee shop with people there ALL DAY.  They don't always have samples, you might just have to get lucky.

The food here somewhat reminds me of a medium priced restaurant.. you can get a yummy meal for ~$10 and refill your glass multiples times with water.  And they have plenty of people to clean the tables and clear your dishes once you're done.  They're really speedy about that. 

This used to be my favorite food court ever until I moved to LA-- even though it is still pretty high on my list.

It's SF.
author: Christina G.

description:
This place has been lovingly called my other dining room as it has saved me in my most hungry hour and was on my way between destinations... it's so convenient! Not to mention caters to nearly everyone. It even has a Sur La Table store to inspire you to cook your own food if you happen to visit the pricey Bristol Farms, also in the food court.

Minus one star for it being crowded, having spotty wifi, and the homeless folks coming in and asking for money or food.
author: Bobby M.

description: I really like this place. So many food options and good food. In spite of the fact that this is a food court, you can get a really good quality food here. It's a nicely designed place, in a beautiful shopping center,  great place if you don't want to spend a lot of money at the surrounding restaurants.
author: Jeff M.

description:
Initially I wanted to give a 3.5 star... but it wont let me, so a 3 star it is.

There's no question about the variety of food they have here. I'm especially impressed at the info structure of this massive place itself and the convenience of places to go to before, during, or after dinner. The quality of food may be debatably to some, but I find it 'okay' because its edible and its a quick alternative than going to a fancy  5 star restaurant, or if your if your in a laid back mood ( students, families, tourist alike, etc.) It does get full, especially on weekends, but what I like are the staff there who clean and clear out your table once your done eating (Thank you so much!)

I see this as a place to hang out and chill with friends. Yes, this place is very popular due to the malls and movie theaters floors above (Not to mention a booth to charge your phones and other electronic devices if you cannot find an outlet). The themed holidays are always a plus too! Once in a while they have live entertainment, such as Lion dancing. 

Flashback: (Shopping around, hears loud sound like music and drums) Me: "What is that?" (turns around looks below the level floors) see's Lion dancers around main floor Me: (ecstatic and excited) omg so cool! :D (Take's out phone to record and take pictures
author: Stephany H.

description:
Definitely one of the best food courts I've seen but it of course still maintains a bunch of mainstream joints. Some mainstream to SF, some mainstream in general. I can't lie, I visit daily because I work across the street.

Don't judge me...
author: Diego A.

description:
"But of course" they couldn't call this a "food court", cos it really is a "Food Emporium". Great variety of cuisine, and generally good quality. I thought I was not a fan of malls and definitely not a fan of "food courts". The Westfield has bent my mind. 

While not a "destination" meal place, it is a super  nice complement to the stores (Nordstrom & Bloomingdales ... what other stores would you need?.) AND the theaters which are awesome ( Metreon up the street is withering - I think Target or some other discounter is taking the large space on the ground level).....ahhh but if you look closely it is another Westfield property.

Ok, so on with the food favorites @ the Food Emporium:

Buckhorn Grill: Think roast beef. Get a plate or sandwich. Big Buck (dump the horse radish sauce on it) is a favorite with the string onion fries. 

Beard Papa: Can't  resist a cream puff (nuff said)

Bristal Farms: deli has a good variety of hot food & cold food to take to the table. Hot food is good, although I do question how long those veggies have been under the heat lamp

Thai: (named something like Coriander) have had their noodles ... not bad but not great. Remember we are in a mall. So, if your in the mood for a little Thai .... get in line

Italian: (something like Pasta Moto or Mojo), surprisingly good for this type of joint. I think their pasta is all imported. They cook it correctly & sauces are tasty

They have lots of roaming service people cleaning tables.  It is a bustling environment and great to have the "people watching" entertainment  while dining. The food selection & people watching is like the United Nations. Really 3 stars on average for the food stalls, 4 stars for the variety of joints & cleanliness. Ok, well and 5 stars to witness the mall dining crowd.... priceless.
author: Matsuo U.

description: i gotta say one of the best food courts in a mall ever.  hands down.  sorabol and beard papa are the tops! also got vegan and japanese and mediterranean and italian and bbq and soup and salad. you name it and it has it.  not just like panda express or burger king.  top notch places.  i come here just for the food sometimes! great that bart stops right here too. free water everywhere and you just leave your stuff on the table.  someone will pick it up.  such great service.  gets crowded though so try to steal some tables early.
author: Matthew G.

description: Love this place very clean, food are awesome, lots of shops to look at and buy, have free WiFi and comfortable seatings. Just hate it when security aren't around when crimes or robbery are in progress, also security don't do anything when homeless are in the mall.
author: C T.

description: This place has a variety of places to eat. But most of the food is overpriced. Many long lines. Hard to find a table to sit at. Your food on your tray gets cold before you find a table. Bristol Farms is like the only place to get good priced food. The food court at the Stones Town mall is better.
author: Isaac H.

description: I don't like the sarku japan in Westfield they give you small servings not like other branches where they have a full to go box filled with food.. I still love their teriyaki chicken and the shrimp it's just too little of a serving for $8.99.. Their restaurants is a little bit messy when it's lunch time they don't have time to check if the tables were clean
author: Kathzell M.

description:
Where else can you go to ONE location and have a billion restaurants surrounding you? 

at the Westfield in SF.

There's everything from Bear Papas to Thai food to Fish and Chips.  And if you don't want anything to eat and you just want a snack or a drink, there's a BRISTOL FARMS.  

Never have I been to a mall and seen a high end grocery store.  It was pretty awesome.  This is the place to go if you're hungry and you have no idea what the hell it is that you want to consume.
author: Jenn C.

description:
OH MY GOODNESS! Talk about a food overload!

The food court at The San Francisco Centre is amazing. There are tons of different options and something for everybody, even the pickiest eater.

Prices are reasonable, though some places are cheaper than others, and some places give you more food for your buck.

My favorites are:
Coriander - Thai food
Sorabol - Korean BBQ
Bistro Burger - burgers and fries
Buckhorn Grill - burgers, salads, sandwiches, BBQ
San Francisco Soup Company - pretty self explanatory ;)
Catch Isle - seafood

For more "sit-down" places, I LOVE the Nordstrom Cafe on the 4th floor and also STRAITS restuarant  - great for HH and sharing small plates.

It can get insanely crowded and there's no "good" time to go so just bear with the crowds and happy eating!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Okay, I admit this is the best food court I've probably ever been to. But still...it's too pricey for a meal while I'm shopping. I'm already spending so much on clothes...why spend so much extra on food too?

But if I were to choose my favorite restaurant out of this bunch, it would be the Thai place! I like their curry..it's super filling. Oh yeah, the Korean place is also not bad. They give pretty big portions, and it tastes pretty legit. 

I also like beard papa's, and gelato. Too bad they closed the tea place that was here...it was good!
author: Jeanette S.

description:
About the most gourmet and expensive food court I have ever witnessed, and you pay more than an average food court as well.

I like:
-Lots of options
-Friendly service
-Convenient location

I do not like:
-Loud
-Can be dirty.  Seems they could use more bussing
-I have been solicited by bums while sitting and eating, but to their credit, the mall staff came by and made the bum give my friend back her money and apologize

the options seem to change rather often as restaurants go out of business and are replaced.
author: Lauren J.

description:
So I used to think was the greatest upscale mall food court of all time.  Until last week I would have mentioned about all the great food selections; Buckhorn Grill, Bistro Burger, Andale, Haagen Dazs, etc... 

Here's my experience:

Last week I noticed cockroach walking on my tray...WHILE I WAS EATING! Eww.. This is unacceptable for a hole-in-the-wall in the T-Loin and especially unacceptable at the Westfield San Francisco Centre. I was enjoying an excellent Bistro Burger at the former Asqew Grill location.  The initial reaction was shock followed by disgust.  Haven't been back since!

I took a couple low-quality photos using my phone (and posted them on Yelp in the photos section).

Before mentioning any of this on Yelp, I email mall management as I wanted them to be aware of the situation and provide an opportunity to respond. They're unedited response: 
"Thank you for taking the time to write about your negative experience as it is crucial we receive this type of feedback in order to keep the center at its best for our patrons. I have forwarded this information
onto our Operations Manager who will handle the situation immediately."

I have no clue what "immediate" response was taken, but I hope the mall maintains a minimum sanitary standard as one would expect for an upscale San Francisco tourist destination.

In all fairness, I would rate four/five stars if not for this one-time experience. I'll surely be back, but only after I give the Operations Manager sufficient time to immediately handle the situation.
author: Nathan E.

description: This is not your typical food court at the mall. Westfield may have fine dining on its top most floor, but I'd rather eat here as there are plenty of options to choose from for everyone from meat lovers, to seafood lovers, and even a vegan option. I prefer eating at either Buckhorn (they serve tri-tip sandwiches which I absolutely love) or Catch Isle ($6.50 for 3 Piece Fish & Chips). If I wanted a deli-style sandwich, I'll go to Bristol Farms. If I wanted a snack, I'll buy some fries at Calbee. Plenty of desert options too from Beard Papa and gelato to Häagen-Dazs. Definitely the best mall food court in San Francisco and possibly the entire Bay Area.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
The Westfield San Francisco Centre Food Emporium reminded me of the food court inside of  the Santa Monica mall. Unlike many other malls in the United States, these food courts offer a variety of gourmet food at reasonable prices. (Although some restaurants are a bit overpriced)

My boyfriend and I were going to try Burger Bar inside of the Westfield Mall but did not have enough time to eat there before our movie. We decided to eat in the Food Emporium and had a great time dining there. 

I ordered the Korean BBQ short ribs from Sorabol and he ordered some $5.00 fish and chips. Both of our dishes were delicious.
author: Lisa H.

description:
In this food court, I've tried Buckhorn Grill, Coriander Gourmet Thai, Kichi Grill, Beard Papa Sweets Cafe, San Francisco Soup Company, and
Sorabol Korean BBQ & Asian Noodles. They're are so many to choose from and I like that they're better than your ordinary eateries in typical food courts.

This place is convenient because they have a mixture of all different kinds of gourmet food! Thai, Italian, American, they have it all! It's super busy on the weekends but the weekdays, it's easier to find seats. 

The great thing is that all eateries use silverware and china. No paper plates or plastic folks around here. They always have workers bussing tables so you won't have to. 

Not everyone knows this unless you frequent the restrooms here but they have sinks outside of the restrooms, yes sinks! I was amazed too when I first saw it 'cause I didn't want to wait in line just to wash my hands after I ate. The wash area is always clean and they even have an sinks for kids. When my boyfriend and I were done eating our food, he was amazed too, lol.

The food here is really good though but one must try it. I'll keep it to the Emporium only since there's separate business reviews for the eateries.

Happy dining!
author: Jessica R.

description: Ate sushi at Westfield mall in San Francisco. Rice was still warm so assume that they rolled it after I ordered it. Two rolls cut into eight pieces. Looked like real crab in calif roll. Rice did not look like Japanese round grain. Inside mall in basement so you can get here via BART Powell Station
author: Clifford W.

description:
I love eating here! There isn't that many restaurants in the heart of downtown in my opinion. I love eating here because you can get the non-typical mall food. Well you can if you walk over to the old mall side. When I think of mall food I think of snacks not a good quality meal but you can get it here. 

This place gives off a more upscale feeling. There is so many to choose from! I should be more adventurous though. I usually order from the Korean place. There isn't that many Korean places in town. I don't think there is any near downtown SF. 

They also have Thai, Italian, Japanese, burgers, steaks, etc.

There is a lot of seating also but I am giving them 4 stars because at times it gets sooo crowded its hard to find seats and the lazy leave your food at the table when you are done thing cause there isn't that many garbage cans around. They hire people to take your trash. 

O there is a Bristol Farms there for anyone who needs to do grocery shopping... Weird... I know.. I like browsing and looking at some of the ridiculously priced things they sell.
author: Sarah C.

description:
OK, I've added a star because it certainly has a few better choices than the food court at Stonestown or Tanforan, but besides 'Out the Door' most of the food seems uneventful and overpriced, plus, you have to scout out a table holding a tray and the atmosphere sucks.  
And you still have to go inside the Mall to get there.  Anywhere else, please.
author: Rob B.

description:
This is where I get dragged because my friend adores the muscles and fries a restaurant here makes.

They're her addiction.

And I don't argue least I get teeth marks in my arm.

So I searched vainly for either Dim Sum or Sushi. And didn't find either. I did however find a Thai place and ordered the cashew chicken and pad thai.

I must tell you, they were delicious. Rivaled Osha on Union, they did. And *cough* for around half the price.

I went and picked up some fruit from Bristol and I was set. Thanks Westfield.
author: Meg T.

description:
High-end shopping center food courts such as this one are fairly common in other parts of the world (a couple that I've been to in Sydney and in Singapore immediately come to mind), but other than this one I don't recall having seen any in California.  

I've only eaten at the Japanese and Korean stores here (if I don't include Beard Papa and Pete's), and I can honestly say that they're as as good as any reasonably priced Japanese or Korean restaurants I've been to in the Bay Area.  Given the shortage of truly decent food options in this touristy part of town, and the number of times I've found myself in the area and completely famished, I'm quite thankful this emporium exists.
author: Zain K.

description: Maybe on of the most eclectic food courts in a mall I've encountered. Not counting the Mall of America which is the size of corporation headquarters, this place has many ethnicities, high brow, low brow, quick and sitdown. The tri tip at Buckhorn, the puffs at Beard Papa, and the Seafood at Catch are alone enough to have a decent meal, but there's tons of other things that I would try and then other I wouldn't touch with your ten foot pole. Again, something for everyone...
author: Kim N.

description: This mall is beautiful and huge! I love this place =)
author: Tiff W.

description:
Unlike any other mall food court in the States. That I've been to. In my head the Mall of America, which has a roller coaster inside, probably has a kicking food court. But that may be just in my head.

There are not only vegan choices (Loving Hut) that distinguish this food court from your typical mall food court filled with sbarro/mcdonald's/taco bell/chinese fast food options, but they serve with real china and silverware for environmental reasons. Staff is always floating around to bus your dishes and keep the place neat and clean. There are no harsh florescent lights giving everyone a ghastly pallor. Instead, the soothing decor and lighting almost invokes zen. In a mall food court, I know! 

Food vendors are also located in the middle of the seating areas, creating a nice flow and separation. But it does make it hard to avoid temptations when two of them are Beard Papa and Gelato stands. We failed miserably to resist Beard Papa. Trying to hold a meeting at a table next to Beard Papa as they crank out fresh and delicious pastries is not a good idea. But man, caving in to that can hardly be considered a weakness... right?

For the most part, prices are fine. $10 avg pp will get you a hearty meal.
author: Kim K.

description: This is my favorite Friday night out place w my husband. we love coming here to see a movie at a century theater, grab a bite at a food court downstairs or if we have more time- at one of the restaurants on the third floor. You can also do some shopping in between, or walk around this beautiful mall. Sometimes we can grab some truffles in one of the chocolatiers, or an ice cream, or a smoothy.... You can find everythingunder one roof here and have a great night out.
author: Diana K.

description: This mall houses quite possibly the best food court I have ever seen in a mall.  You could have something different every day for two weeks and probably still have options left.
author: Dave C.

description: I always visit this place in the "Emporium Basement" as we used to call it. My favorite is Sorabel, the portions are huge enough for two people to eat. Love the Korean dishes and noodles! I'm only in San Francisco once a year but I never miss it!
author: Rob G.

description: Probably one of the best food courts, huge selection and many different ethnic foods. You also got your healthy and your comfort, your made to order and your pre-made. You may also drink in the food court, and when you are done you leave your mess!!!!
author: Tim V.

description:
As far as food courts go, Westfield's food court is a pretty good one. You get the usual overpriced mall food but the court is large and has a good variety of eateries.

What puts this at four stars is all the free samples! I repeat free samples!

+ Buckhorn Grill's free tri-tip steak sample. Chomp! Delicious!
+ Jody Maroni's free samples of sausages! Chomp! Chomp! Chomp! Delicious!
+ Free crepe sample... chomp!
+ Free chicken teriyaki sample... chomp!
+ Free Korean sample... chomp!

Do you really still need to buy something after making a round? I'll let your tummy decide.
author: Sam T.

description: Great mall if your looking for anything. They have the upper end items and the lower end items for everyone who visits. Their food court isn't all that great, not many options that appealed to me.
author: Kia S.

description:
Definitely, the nicest food court that I've ever been to in my life, life, life....
Too hard to pick what kind of food I wanted but settled on Hana..... (forgot the entire name).  Some good shrimp tempura with rice and veggies - $9.99.  And what surprised me is that they serve their food in actual dishes, not some styrofoam or paper product.
author: Jen S.

description:
Really bad the service, very expensive! No friendly!!!

I asked them question and they were rude answering! No friendly, very demanding.

Sushi bad.
author: Mauro P.

description: Great place to grab a meal anytime during the day.  They have so many options to choose from that anyone can find something they like/want.  Personally I prefer Charlie's or Andele.  Andele has really good Mexican food (and not fast food type Mexican).  Charlie's is like a Great Steak Escape and offers a wide range of delicious sandwiches.  Prices are a bit high but normal for SF.  Great dining option in Downtown SF.
author: Robert G.

description:
As far as a food court goes, this is as good as it gets. I worked a conference this week, and a bunch of out-of-towners asked me for suggestions on good places to eat & quite frankly, I think the SF Center Food Court is the best option. Union Square isn't known to be a location for good, casual dining - it's filled with tourist-trap restaurants. NO ONE from SF actually eats at those restaurants unless it's the high high end ones. As far as walk-in casual dining, definitely not. I would frequent the food court when I worked at the mall, but by no means did I ever complain about having to be subjected to "mall food" because let me tell you - SF mall food is not your typical mall food. I would suggest:

*Beard Papa's cookie crunch cream puff with vanilla bean custard
*Amoura's pesto pasta salad
*Melt's gelato (strawberry, pistachio, & cookies-and-cream flavors in particular) -- the best gelato I've ever had
*Buckhorn's tri-tip steak sandwich 
*Sobabol's Korean BBQ ribs & clear noodles

I heard the Vietnamese food at "Out The Door" is great too, but I've personally never been. 

No plastic forks or paper plates at this food court. Nope - real silverware and nice plates to go with it. Leave your tray at the tables and the nice staff will come and clear them away for you. This is a great food court that can accomodate your cravings - no matter what they are.
author: Denise L.

description:
This food court is nuts. It has EVERY type of cuisine known to mankind on top of the "straight to my hips" desserts. Higher end restaurants. No McDonald's or Panda Express (which can be found at the other end of the mall) but places like Andale and Beard Papa. MmMmMm...

Everything looks so elegant. No need to bus your own table as there is a waiter-type staff who stand around ready to pounce on your utensils once you leave. Very professional, very friendly, and I appreciate what they do.

The first time there, I saw people bring their own wine, pop it open, and sit in their small tables. I wasn't sure if I should have held a tray with my food piled on top in fear that I was looking bad or not elegant enough. Should have worn my prom dress.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
This is the nicest food court I have been to. No matter what restaurant you get food from, it feels clean! I don't know of any other malls that can pull that off.

I've been to a 4 or 5 restaurants in there, but my favorite dish is from the Mexican food place, Andale, their shrimp nachos are awesome. The rolled tacos from there are really good too, but the place is a bit pricey. Bistro burger has great burgers too, and of course you have to try a crepe from Melt...
author: Brandon R.

description:
I'm a fan. 

The reason I like this place is because it's right next to a huge parking lot. Everything is easy to get to. I can park and then walk across the street and it's Westfield Food Court. 

It's one of the better food courts that's available in San Francisco. Lots of selection and has 2 coffee shops (starbucks and peets).
author: Eric Y.

description:
Upscale design on the inside. The food courts were nothing cheap. It was about $10 for a plate of fried prawns and french fries at one place - which were quite good, actually. 

Friend noted that their bathrooms - architecturally speaking - are very upscale.

This is someplace that I wouldn't mind taking some out-of-towners if we were already in the mall and hungry for food. Dinner would still be in the Mission, though.

The only reason this is 3 stars instead of 4 is the price.
author: Andrew L.

description: Skip Amoura.  The sandwich I had was mostly bread and tasteless.  In addition, the prices were high.  $11 for sandwich and drink only.
author: Djl D.

description:
When you step inside this food court, your eyes wander everywhere! Where do you start?  Ahhhhhh...Free tasting samples! 

Chomp..Chomp...Nom..Om...Om....!!

Your eyes and stomach are telling you to get this or that...no...wait...how about... that looks good...wait...I see....Cream puffs (*drool), pizza, Korean BBQ, sandwiches, burritos, pasta, tri-tip, gelato, crepes, salad, hot dog, smoothies, and more and more....(*double drool*) 

This food court is a great place to grab yummy and affordable food if you have no idea what you want, but you have so many choices to choose from all the varieties.  

Enjoy eating and sampling those yummy bites!
author: Deborah C.

description: Compared to most other malls I've been to, the Powell St. Mall seems to have much better food at its food court. I've been to Coriander Thai a couple times - and it's impressive for being semi-fast food. And the cheese and bacon-bit fries at Charley's are mouth-watering. Other restaurants include San Francisco Soup Company (bread bowls! although you could go to Boudin's at Fisherman's Wharf nearby for something even better), Sorabol Korean BBQ (pretty standard), a mediterranean restaurant, an american-style burger and sandwich restaurant, and even a vegan restaurant. There's a Bristol Farms inside the mall next to the food court as well. Although it gets very crowded, it's definitely worth checking out.
author: Michael T.

description:
By far, thee best FoodCourt around.  Picture all your favorite sit down restaurants, minus the waiter and cheaper!  You even still get real plates and silverware!

You won't find any Hot Dog on Sticks or Sbarros here!

My favorite is Sorabol Korean BBQ and Teazme :)
author: Earlene C.

description:
Well, what can you say? This is straight out of an episode of "Extreme Food Court Makeovers." Beard Papa, Askew Grill, Bistro Burger, Buckhorn Grill, etc. Lots of options, something for everyone, and it ain't fast food.

So why only two stars? Well, although the food has potential, the food court itself is the perfect setting for someone to get something stolen, which is exactly what happened to a friend of mine the other day. Though it probably wasn't a good idea to hang her purse from the back of her chair, whoever did it had no regard for the four people at the table, as well as the hundreds of people that were around us. Hey, I should give them credit, no one noticed a thing. Some kind of inside job, perhaps? I guess desperate times call for desperate measures, and I understand folks gotta survive by any means necessary, but I would hate to go back to see some other would-be thief try to take it up a notch. 

Thanks, but no thanks.
author: Jack D.

description: the workers of westfield mall need clean up the trash when people finish eating, were talking about pile of pile of tray of left over food from customer... saw some tray sitting on tables for 20 minutes plus until some notice or no westfield people can be found. FAIL!
author: JessePanda C.

description: A great place to shop and hangout. The food court has great choices along with a Jamba Juice. Bloomingdale and Nordstorm for high end window shopping. There is also great mother's room in Nordstorm to tend to babies.
author: Gopi V.

description:
As a yelper I love food and hearing the word "Food Court" may sound like a negative connotation because I associate that with cheap fast food chains at the mall. However, going to the Westfield food court in San Francisco will blow you away.

The food court reminds me of those in Asia that are situated in high end cities and malls and are decorate beautifully. This food court has a modern decor feel with a wide range of quality restaurants serving you dishes in a fast and efficient manner. Almost all of the places serve fine wine to accommodate your meal. They have Korean BBQ, fancy Thai food, Beard Papas, steak places, seafood places, fancy market etc. Unlike other food courts where you need to clean up and place the plates back by the trashcans, they have people come and take your plates for you! The dishes that the places serve you are real forks and knives, no plastic and paper stuff.

I would think this food court is comparable if not better than the one in Century City mall near Beverly Hills.
author: Charles P.

description: Coriander Gourmet Thai and San Francisco soup company best places to eat. Order sweet basil chicken, spicy catfish it's great.
author: Chris M.

description: As far as food courts go, it doesn't get much better.  I'd give it 5 stars if they would have had the foresight to build it all the way upstairs under the dome instead of in the basement.  It needs natural light.  Aside from that, if you're hungry for it, you'll find it here.  Great healthy options as well as burgers and BBQ.  Lots of comfortable seating and for as much traffic as this place gets, it's always very clean.  Custodial staff are plentiful clearing and cleaning tables quickly even at peak hours.
author: Jeff M.

description: Other than shopping and eating at their food court...The Westfield San Francisco Centre Food Emporium for me is a really neat & very cool place to hang out!!! The one place that, I like the most of all at The Westfield is going to the top floor and to sit down on the chair that they have and to relax and stay away from the busy & noisy streets of Market Street!!!
author: William B.

description:
The food court is pretty awesome and will satisfy even the most indecisive person.  Me.  I like how they have a variety of food options and it's not your usual food stands like Panda Express, Sbarro's etc.  Umm...I guess if you're craving that, you can just walk across the way to the SF Centre Food Court. :P

The dining area is pretty huge and I like how they have counter height seating, which helps if you're a party of one.

One thing however that I like yet dislike at the same time is that many if not all of the food stands use actual plates and silverware.  Yeah, it's better for the environment, no doubt but, I just hate leaving a tray on the table just for someone else to clean not to mention, trying to find a table or spot and there's a tray with dirty plates on them with nowhere to move them to.

Other than that, it's a great spot!!
author: Nick D.

description:
A plethora of food to choose from :) I do stop by for the food whenever I have time or whenever I eat out with a friend/s or just me solo. 

It's an upgraded version of food court. They just need extra cleaning crew.

I recommend this one for the food choices :D
author: Pierre B.

description:
I went down there once and I was very hungry.  I felt totally claustrophobic and then I saw the name of one restaurant, Beard Papa.  Ok, I think I just lost my appetite.  I felt like I wanted to get the hell out of there.

I'll try to go back again and actually eat something and update my review.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
In general I despise food courts, buffets and chain restaurants.  They always lack originality, any sense of healthiness and are general all the same old shtick.

This food court however is a lesson in what proper planning and visionary management can do.  Most of the vendors are off shoots of already established local eateries, most of whom are committed to local and sustainable product.  Although sadly the public in general seems clueless to this fact.  The place is perpetually busy which is a compliment to the wide variety of foods (no duplications) and the quality.  None of the places I've tried have been bad.  Some better than others, but taste is subjective.  I also find it quite an achievement there has been little turnover in vendors since its inception.  

Kudos to Westfield management for doing something special here.  Now if they could just import that same sensibility into the rest of their malls across the country .... one can hope.
author: Russell D.

description:
Best food court ever! The only thing I don't like is how crowded it gets. It's a victim of its own success. I read in some urban planning blogs that the best way to ensure availability of parking is to charge for it. Maybe that's why there is never any seating here... there's no cost to people to sit here.

Beard Papa is so very good. Melt is pretty mediocre gelato. Froots has good smoothies. Bristol Farms has great prepared foods. Coriander, Sorabol, and Asqew Grill have generous portions of restaurant-quality food. What's not to like?

Based on all of the "don't take your booze past this line" signs around the food court, I think some of the places even serve beer and wine. And that can only adds to the feeling of dining in an actual restaurant, right?
author: Sharon W.

description: In the basement of the Westfield Mall in downtown San Francisco, there is a food court with a number of restaurants providing good quality food at great prices. The Buckhorn Grill is one of these restaurants. It is known for its world famous tri-tip but they also have a number of entree salads that are delicious and very filling. I recently had the Crispy Chicken Avocado and loved it!  The dressing is delicious and the romaine lettuce is crisp. If you want a salad that is filling and fresh, just try one of their 7 entree salads. You will not be disappointed.
author: Joanne F.

description:
Yesterday, for the first time, we visited the food court (or Emporium, as they call it rightfully so) @ the Westfield Centre by Market St. We were SO impressed: we expected the traditional franchises yet found none of them (fortunately). There were so many great options to eat that it made it really hard to choose, but we settled on Buckhorn a great place to eat Trip-Tip (Punta Trasera, para los venezolanos) at a "reasonable" price. We got a plate with the meat, veggies and a glass of wine for a little over $13.

We will be coming back: to Buckhorn and the Emporium, in future visits to the city.
author: Manny H.

description:
So my lunch hour usually goes a little something like this: 

Weave through the crowd to seek out the following: A sample of Buckhorn's tri-tip. A sliver of pizza. Teriyaki chicken. And if I'm lucky a crepe sample (my favorite!). 

After purchasing food, if for some reason the sample person was not there the first time around (most likely to refill their platters), a 2nd attempt would be needed. 

Yep. It's like going to Costco every day! 

Onto the actual review: One of the nicest food courts I've seen so far. Most of them seem more like mini restaurants versus the usual fast food crap you have come to expect. However, that all comes with a price. 4 stars because I'm going broke spending all my money on lunch.
author: Vivian D.

description: Shit this place is always packed especially during lunch hour. Love what everybody has to offer but I do miss Asquew and Tom's cookies. Been meaning to try Papa beards cream puffs
author: EmmettsGuRL C.

description: This is a pretty decent food court especially for a MALL. They have a couple places I like to grub on. Such as Buckhorn Grill Salads, Bristol Farms Soup & Salad, Sorabol for quick already made Korean BBQ, Out The Door for different Asian dishes, and Catch something or another. A seafood place of some sort. I wouldn't probably come here very much if I hadn't worked upstairs in the mall, but the food is decent. While some places are a definitely no go (Mr. Hana) the other places make up for it.
author: Natasha S.

description: Best "food court" you'll ever find. We got there twice during our weeklong S.F. trip to get a sweet treat (espresso gelato) from Melt was good. My husband liked the cupcakes from Bristol Farms and the cream puffs from Beard Papa. If you're looking for something fun and fancy had to the other end of the Westfield mall and go to the cafe at Nordstorm's and try their Goat Cheese Tart...Yum!
author: Carrie M.

description:
definitely one of the best food courts to hit. In fact, I cant' think of a better one here in the states. Most of the restaurants are totally different and upscale from the usual.  In other words, you WILL NOT find Sbarro, Burger King, Hot Dog on a Stick, Panda Express nor nameless barely-in-business hoagies here.  Good Riddance. Instead, there are some great high quality ethnic food choices (Thai, Vietnamese, American Grill, etc)  and a couple of excellent dessert snack places (Gelato, Beard Papa) to boot. 

If you are from out of town, say, here for Oracle OpenWorld or any other convention over at Moscone,  this is a great out-of-the-way from the convention place to sneak off to to get a quick bite in between presentations.   Again, it's not the ordinary mall food court, and that's why I like it.    The only food court better than this is the one I experienced in Singapore - but that's a story for another time. =)
author: Harry W.

description:
What a shit-show this mall is. I go for the spectacle, which isn't Felliniesque at all. Who are these people? I don't know but I enjoy them. I never see these people anywhere else in the city. The girls here are amazing, -- the greatest knockouts have the most terrible boyfriends I've ever seen. I see girls who look pretty classy arm in arm with these waif-thin, veiny, sallow-skinned punks with the standard unbent baseball cap, jeans around the knees, and UFC shirt XXLarge. Now, teenagers will always dress like assholes and that's fine and how it should be. But teenagers have been dressing like this for 20 fucking years. I want to see this evolve a little. If you're going to sag your pants, why not pioneer something new? I have some ideas. Sure you could increase the sag and drop them around your ankles, -- that's pretty brave. But if you want to take it to the next level, why not try the Ectopic Sag? You take a pantleg and tie it around your shin and just drag the rest of the pants behind you. 

None of this really matters because I missed my own point: these teenagers are in their fucking 30's. 

The guy from Hotchickswithdouchebags.com should assign an intern to camp out here. 

Let's look at some positives: this is a hipster-free environment. No irony here. There's no a millimeter of art or self-consciousness to be found inside this space. There's also a kind of game to be made out of dodging the barrage of perfume/cologne sellers and massage therapists. And lastly there's a food court downstairs. 

I like Jamba Juice. I like the vegan asian place. There's a nice ramen place too. Panda Express is the Taco Bell of chinese food, which is either an insult or a compliment depending on your tastes. I have little nice to say about Bristol Farms. However, if you're too lazy to scramble some eggs on a Saturday morning and go buy some in a box at Bristol Farms, maybe you should be charged $20. The cheesesteak place tastes good but somehow too rich for my stomach. I really want to like the soup place (it's a chain) but none of the soups do it for me. I've really tried, though. 

There are I think five or six frozen yogurt places throughout the mall and four or five chocolate shops. 

There's a movie theater upstairs. 

There are some restaurants upstairs also but I haven't tried any of them.
author: Bill G.

description:
