Food emporium sounds very lah dee dah doesn't it? However, let me assure you that this is no ordinary food court.

There's not a golden arch in sight! Instead, you'll find a variety of eat in or take out options of great quality. I spent an age wandering round Bristol Farms which offers a supermarket as well as ready to eat food.

Being SF, there are a lot of oriental options with Chinese, Japanese and Korean food represented. There's also Mexican and Italian as well as steak and seafood outlets. To be honest, at lunchtime, you could probably just wander round and fill up on the many free samples being handed out.

In the end, I settled for a bowl of Korean noodles with assorted BBQ meat and what else for dessert but froyo from Cefiore. I almost succumbed to a Beard Papa pastry to compare it to London but my very full stomach told me to stop!
author: Yee Gan O.

description:
Ok, so I hate malls.

But this one has a nice food court.

So I hate it a little less.
author: Matthew R.

description:
OK, should I be embarrassed that I like to spend my Friday nights (and money) at this food court?? 

No, because as the other reviews say, this isn't your typical food court.  I expected the prices to be sky rocketing high, but it is reasonable for the proportions. It's family friendly, hired help cleans up after you, and I love how there are many options and I don't have to drive all over the place (and find parking) to just taste these meals. You will see restaurants such as: 

Out the door
Catch Isle
Coriander gourmet thai
Pasta moto
Mr Hana
Andale

And my current fav: 
Melt gelato & Crepe Cafe   
(Who doesn't like crepes?!   The "street crepe" + scoop of gelato is my favorite).

After a good eat, you can go catch a movie at the movie theatre in the mall, or stroll around the mall and shop.
author: KatsuCat D.

description: Pretty decent food court! Found just what I was craving
author: Rosie S.

description:
When I first moved here, my man said to me, "Hey, why don't I take you out to the mall food court?" I thought we'd reached a new low in our relationship. The words 'MALL....FOOD....COURT" strung together in a sentence bring to mind thoughts of awkward high school times, greasy fast food, free Chinese chicken samples, and maybe 80s movies..... but not any sort of date-related venture. 

While you may run into free chicken samples (and quite a few other delicious free nibbles to try), this is not your momma's food court. High end, TONS of options (yes, even for vegetarians like myself)- all of them delicious and for the most part reasonably priced. Bristol Farms is not exactly cheap, but this is the type of market that kind of makes me want to run around, pick up apples and toss them around and sing "The Hills are Alive".... or something. Anyway, it's nice. I recommend sandwich counter, pizza, fresh salad, or any of the fresh fruit & veggies.

As someone who is perpetually changing ingredients on menu items, I am also a huge fan of the SF Soup company's salads- SO MANY great fresh things to shove into, on, around, and generally all over your mixed up greens it could make you satisfied all day. 

There's also a slew of other choices - Mexican, Chinese, Japanese, Crepes... you name it, it's here. Just don't look for McDonald's, cause this place is too good for that.  

And while, yes, this is still a food court- I'm not doing a total 180 here claiming they've got white tablecloths and candles- it is a much, much better food court than any other I can remember (save for one in Switzerland.... yes, SWITZERLAND. But they had really good icecream)- good enough even for a date. Well, a lunch date anyway. But not a first date. More of a "I've known you for ten years and don't really need to impress you anymore" date.... oh wait, I didn't say that. 

Good stuff. Go. Eat. SHOP.
author: Kristen L.

description: My absolute favorite is Sorobol's Spicy BBQ chicken with the clear rice noodles. I think its around $9, but the portion size is HUGE. I always have leftovers after leaving here. This is my go to spot when I'm in the city. If you are unsure of what to eat at the mall, ask them for a sample and I can guarantee that you will fall in love with that chicken just as I have.
author: Erika L.

description:
This place is absolutely ridiculous. Its a love hate relationship, really. 

Its always packed, the employees at the food stands arent the brightest but the variety is amazing and they usually have quite a few sample people out!
author: Britney K.

description:
I come here almost everyday since I work only half a block from there.  I love that each place gives out samples.  If I wanted to, i can just do 3 rounds and I am sure I would be full.

Here  is the list of the favorite places:

1) Buckhorn - Salad with beef
2) Peets - coffee
3) Bristol Farms - poki salad
3) Andale - chips and guac
4) Pasta Moto - salads and roasted veggies
5) San Francisco Soup Company - salad wraps
6) Coriander - spring rolls and chicken wings
7) Out the Door - I like this place, but its rather expensive
author: Janet S.

description:
Coming here during the lunch rush on a week day I couldn't help but feel overwhelmed with a sense of deja vu. Where was this odd familiarity coming from? Oh, now I remember. It's like a grown up high school cafeteria. 

Amongst all the downtown types there was an air of frenzied eating and social activity before having to head back to the office (chemistry 2.) The cliques were easy enough to spot. There were the ladies of leisure who shop professionally (cheerleaders,) the suits (jocks) talking about how much money (ass) they pull, IT guys (nerds,) high school kids playing hooky trying to look cool (freshmen) and the lonely secretaries eating their lunch in blissful solitude (me.)

There's a wide variety of watered down, ethnic-type chain restaurants. You can get an $8 Vietnamese sandwich or a $10 burrito. I'm not going to bemoan the fact that most of the food is overpriced in a city that is saturated with great, cheap ethnic restaurants because we are, after all, talking about a mall food court. So, by that standard, this place is pretty fucking swank. All I'm saying is don't expect to find a Panda Express or Hot Dog On a Stick here. If that's what you're looking for, go next door to the old San Francisco Centre, you fucking juvenile. This place is for the big kids.

Despite my less than fond memories of high school I do have to give the Westfield Food Emporium an extra star for the marked absence of wedgies and wet willies being freely and indiscriminately doled out.
author: Josua P.

description:
Wanna have a really great laugh here?  Do what I did this past Saturday, 8/25/2007 at 6.17pm.

First, gather a small group of friends, two or three should suffice.

Next, go there at a PEAK meal time -- lunch or dinner during the weekend -- and make your way past the screaming babies, portly tourists, and poseur hipsters who think hanging in the food court of the Westfield Mall is the NEW new place to be seen.

As you are walking through the court -- I chose the spot between Mr. Hana and Bistro Burger, but you may prefer another locale -- scream the following in the most obnoxious, queeny voice you can muster: 

"WHY THE FUCK DID YOU BITCHES BRING ME TO A FOOD COURT?!? I'M A FUCKING ANOREXIC!!!!"

Good times, good times.
author: d s.

description:
I saw a, long light brown-blond-ish hair + face lift, late 30, Asian woman w/ very short & tight light blue vinyl-skirt , red high heel w/bare feet, of course, nice pedicure though, white tank top w/ perfect round cantaloupe like bosom, very skanky lookin',
she was sitting right next to ......
a family, 2 babies were crying so hard in a stroller, the pap, about 40, lookin White-male was w/ shorts & sports sandals w/ socks, look like old female. The mom was also white, tired, late 30, No make-up, looked,  like...... a guy.

And some teenage girls were showing off their cleavage and navel and followed by a bunch of boys look like...... such a...... Dumb Ass Mutha Fokers, ....reminded me of that when I was the age.....

What a awesome view.
Great! Just great.

I think food is a bit pricy but not too bad in here.
But I like the produce market and large deli.
Korean BBQ place was good,
Grilled Steak place was good,
But, the Japanese place calls "Hana" is a tipical Pseudo Japo by Korean, the poke over rice was $12.- ! that's rip off !
author: Nobu K.

description:
High-end mall cafeteria. 

There are people hired to bus the table when you're full from eating and you can't take your own garbage to the garbage bin.  Most of the servings are HUGE and placed on nice white ceramic bowls and plates, instead of the paper plates and togo boxes you would get at other cafeterias. 

But if you don't want to spend a whole lot of money on a delicious burrito, go to the mission. It's cheaper, better tasting and people I feel sorry for aren't hovering over you waiting to take your plate and clean your table after you.
author: Caryl C.

description:
Two stars for the great variety and higher quality standards than typical mall food fare. 

If you have children or very short people in your party, leave them at home. The pack of wild animals in this "emporium" are rude, inconsiderate, and harried and your miniature loved ones will pay the price. Some suit knocked over my friend's baby's stroller (with the baby in it!) and just kept walking. My itty-bitty friend Sara was physically moved out of some woman's way near Beard Papa. The crowds are unmanageable and the noise level makes my head spin. Love Bristol Farms and that's the only reason I venture down here. I'd rather walk up to the other end of Union Square for lunch and maintain what sanity I have left. 

I guess if I worked in the area, I would be inclined to get takeout here but that's about the only way I can imagine spending more time here.

**There IS ample seating, but you will pay the price in hearing loss and anxiety attacks.
author: Autumn K.

description:
I would love to give this place 5 stars as it is the best mall food court when it comes to the quality of the food. However because it is all so "trendy" and "fancy" they all use sesame seeds/ oil or peanut oil/ peanuts in everything. So I can eat a tri tip sandwich, some of the Asqew items, or a salad (not tossed cause they tongs all put into one water bucket and the miso sesame salad dressing washes off in it and gets on the tongs and makes me sick). So yeah... today I had a cobb salad and tried for about 5 minutes to have the lady understand what an "allergy" is. Food industry- teach your workers to understand the word ALLERGY. The last place I want to stab myself with an epipen is a food court with thousands of people pushing and shoving and not caring what my problem is. 

I WANT TO EAT PAD THAI LIKE EVERYONE ELSE.
author: Ali R.

description:
My review of Coriander pretty much said it.  
http://www.yelp.com/biz/AVmip4P8l2i7HheKuniWvA?hrid=KbMY91ZmucCb5vbOW59m5Q

 It's expensive for a mall food court, but then the mall itself is expensive.  The food down here is a cut above what you'll find in the older part of the mall just to the west.  There are real sit-down eat-in restaurants, as well as the fare that is relegated to the common dining area.  When was the last time you saw real metal tableware and granite table tops in a food court?  The clientele is self-selecting, too.  People eating here appear to be more well-heeled than the people eating in the other food court in the older part of the mall just to the west.  All in all, it's a more upscale dining experience, regardless of the fact that the "food emporium"  is actually ... a food court!
author: David D.

description:
Every time I go in this place I am amazed that it can bring together so many different vendors selling so many different kinds of food, and still utterly fail to offer up anything I really want to eat.

(Exception: Bristol Farms has an amazing hot food bar - but they are union busting scum and I refuse to eat there)

Three stars for mediocre execution of a great idea.
author: Joe C.

description: I don't get the hype about this "food court in a mall" thing. Food courts in a mall is pretty much everywhere in Australia where I live. This food court is very small compared to the ones over here and even much smaller compared to those in Asia. Food is just so-so. The only one I like was the crepes. Delicious and cheap! Well...all food is cheap in the US (compared to Sydney).
author: SC O.

description:
Is this not the BEST mall food court EVER? 

We wandered in here by accident one day, on our way off of  BART.  Now, when we BART, we make it a specific point to get to the city or leave the city RIGHT at dinner, so the family can go to this food court.  So far, I've tried the raw bar and pizza at Bristol Farms (picks by the kids), coffee at Peet's (yeah, can never seem to pass by Peet's without getting a cup), Sorabol (but I think that's kind of standard mall fare, actually), andale, and buckhorn grill (yeah, this one is kind of standard mall fare, too, but I was in the mood for one of those huge salads).

The kicker is that this place is ALWAYS bustling; the only table that we found was this mini table w/ little chairs.  Perfect for 5 year olds.  Except that I'm not five.  My kids loved it, and I -- well, I had good food, so who cares?

I hope I discover more ACCIDENTS like this one.
author: Patty W.

description:
Best food court ever!  

I live really close by and come here whenever I don't want to make dinner.... that means, I'm here a lot.

This is the best food court ever - from Coriander to Buckhorn.  There are some places I don't like though like the Salad/Mediterranean place.  I got food from there once, I think maybe a dip plate or dolmas or something and it was gross.  

Also, another bad thing is that they closed down Tom's cookies, so now I have to walk! (boo exercise) all the way to Macy's to get my fave cupcakes.  

Cheap + quick = wonderful
author: F K.

description:
I really cant stand mall food... No matter how fancy they try to make it. 

There are long lines, dirty tables, messy condiments bars... and a smelly mixture of Chinese food, pizzas, french fries and beyond...

You can never go wrong with the Nordstom's Cafe. :)
author: Dee C.

description: Good food for those on a budget!  Buckhorn Grill has salads that are a healthy & delicious alternative to fast food that's bad for you.  They tend to get busy, but that is simply because others see the value that I do & want good food that's affordable.  In this day & age, that's reason to celebrate.  Have been going there for the past 3 years or so & not been disappointed in any of my choices.
author: Thomas O.

description:
What the hell am I doing giving a mall food court five stars?

Has the world started rotating in the opposite direction?

Did I trade in my fancy-ass messenger bag for a knapsack with "Kimmie" embroidered on the back?

Do I now show up at the roller rink every Saturday at 2 pm so I can jealously dig my nails into my hands as my crush Andy Tiller skates around, hand in hand, with Robin Papigan, to "Last Dance?"

Nope. The food court at this mall - yes, this mall - is that amazing. Tom Colliccio has a restaurant here. There's an outpost of the Slanted Door's fast food concept. There's a full blown Tom's Bakery (the people who make that frozen dough you buy at Trader Joe's). A Korean Fast food concept...like Chipotle, but Korean.  A fish joint. A tea joint. A boring old Peet's. A Bristol Farms (ah, thanks for that little piece of LA flash, yo). Upscale burgers. And a nasty-ass gelato joint that, if I reviewed separately, would fall into the one-star "heartbreakingly bad gelato" category. 

I've never seen such a collection of interesting, high-end restaurant concepts grouped into one place in the US, ever (for those of you who have spent time in Japan and wandered the top floors of department stores, this is old hat). For anyone wondering what's "in" in restaurant concepts these days, this is a must-stop on your itinerary.
author: Lindley E.

description:
Best American mall food court yuppified for downtown SF. 

Or is it?

As I said before, a huge no prize to the intern who came up with the $6 word EMPORIUM to replace food court during the Westfield Marketing Meeting.

There were no Roman gastronomicas here or Swedish smorgasboards. Not even a Roman orgy.

If Westfield SF is supposed to represent the very best of San Francisco, what's a meh BBQ place doing here, or an unheard of place that does pasta, and pizza. Or a pseudo Korean Sorabol mall court place? Or a case of ID crisis of Mr Hana that's not so Japanese and not so Hawaiian (for sure not a little bit country and for sure not a little bit rock and roll).

The crepe and gelato vendor stop is probably the most attractive place of the lot, but does it really represent SF? Andale has fantastic tasting Mexican plates, but $9? Ouch. That's what you get for getting good stuff in a clean environment downtown. And Out The Door? C'mon Charles you can do something better than that....how about something authentic Vietnamese and not a cross fusion of Cantonese comfort food (like congee and oil sticks) with more cases of ID crisis.

If I were able to re-do or re-select vendors I'd pick something like:

1) Get Zuni Cafe to do a food court stall, scaled down, but keep a few signature offerings. Let's face it, Zuni *is* an SF institution amongst foodies, snobs, and people in the know, and I only ate there once years ago (wasn't blown away then, but I respect what they do).

2) Have one of the great Italian places come sign up, and also offered easy scaled down but good food. A16, Delfina, etc come to mind. Heck even Pizzeria Delfina sounds good.

3) Get at least one of the vendors from the SF Ferry Building. Blue Bottle would make a killing here if they could set up shop there. Pranther Ranch would sell chicken sandwiches like crazy I'm sure. 

4) Get the best Chinatown restaurant to the "Emporium" and do strictly authentic Cantonese fare like won ton noodles, cha siu or BBQ meats over rice plate. MAYBE a little bit of dim sum but don't push it. No Mr. Chau's fast food, no Happi House Teriyaki, no Sorabol, no Panda Express, and no crappy steam table supermarket fare.

5) At least several representations of the best ethnic food SF has to offer. I'm sure you have your faves, whether it be Peruvian, Ethiopian etc. But you won't find that in the yuppified mall court.

6) Try to court Thomas Keller into opening an even more scaled down Bouchon kind of place here. After all, what's SF without the signature restaurant, restaraunteur and the cooking they represent? If Tom won't play there are many other worthy contenders.

Bristol Farms? Hmmm too Whole Food-ish, but at the same time not quite. Doh....
author: Ken K.

description:
I've unabashedly raved and recommended this food court to my friends and family. Though, I always have to preface with, "This may sound weird but..." And it does, but if you've been to Asia and experienced their malls (think Taipei 101), then you'll feel right at home at this food court. (Because Asia knows how to do public spaces.)

Yes, it's still a food court but there's nary a Mickey D's or Orange Julius in sight. You want Korean? You want Thai? You want tri-tip with a glass of wine? And some gelato for dessert? Indulge yourself here amidst the refreshingly calm interior design. Yes, the lights may be florescent but the light covers have a lovely leaf design.

They even have an extremely helpful and attentive staff clearing the tables for you. Now that's a food court!

My only complaint (besides closing at 9pm)? The cacophony of the nice wood chairs' metal legs constantly scraping against the faux-marble (?)/concrete floor can drive sensitive ears nuts.
author: Viv C.

description:
Waking up after my SF DYL I was a bit hung over and extremely thankful I had until noon to check out of my wonderful hotel.  I used every last minute in there to rest and recover from the night before.  When it was time to meet GBF#1 in the lobby I finally went down and we deiced on where to grab a bite to eat.  I thought why not check out the Westfield Food Court, I'm sure there would be something down there that my hung over ass would want to eat.  Plus I wanted another Teaz Me ice tea, ice tea is a great hangover cure if you didn't already know.

I think this is the most amazing food court I've seen in the US and they use real plates and silverware.  Plus the tables are kept clear and clean and people didn't mind sharing their space.  Yet another plus the variety of the food they have is amazing, something for everyone.  Salads to Thai food to Korean food to crepes to Mexican food to even Panda Express.  If you're shopping in the area and need a quick bite to eat stop into the Westfield Food Court I'm sure you'll find something to satisfy your hunger, I sure did.
author: Me H.

description:
I love food courts and this one too.  Before this food court opened, our lunch selection was quite limited while shopping downtown.  

I also love Peets!
author: HY L.

description:
plenty of food choices and it does become overwhelming especially when your stomach is growling.

average food that's a little high on the price but the seating arrangements and REAL plate & silverware makes up for it.

i rather have lunch here than the old food court on the other side of the mall. 

favorite places to eat:
Coriander Gourmet Thai
Mr. Hana
BRISTOL FARMS
author: Carol Y.

description:
Think what you want about eating in the malls, but there's no denying that the Food Emporium is the best food court. Not the best in the world (I believe those are in Hong Kong), but the best that SF has to offer. 

The decor is aesthetically pleasing with its natural color scheme, modern chic tables/chairs, and all the bamboo a panda could eat. But even if you are not a panda, you'll find plenty to eat here. The offerings are more upscale than fast food you will normally find in a mall. No Dairy Queens or Panda Expresses. What you get instead is gelato, Coriander Gourmet Thai, Beard Papas, Asqew, etc. 

It's the little things that make a difference here. You have people taking your tray away for you. You get real silverware. You get to pay a little bit more for a lot better food. This is a great place to meet friends, take a break from trying on clothes, or grab a quick bite before your movie. Those small things make this place a favorite outing of many, myself included, of course.

So why not 5 star? Well...

Didn't think you could go back to the pre-cell phone days? This place just may prove you wrong. The lack of cell phone signal (depending on your carrier) could be an issue. Better be clear about the exact time & location you want to meet your friend, and hope that he/she will show up as planned. Cuz if he/she doesn't, I hope you still remember how to use a pay phone.

Some time last year, I also discovered that the chairs are painfully annoying. When the tables around you slide their chairs in & out on the tiles (and there is a lot of this action going on at any given time), it results in a loud, high pitched scratching sound. Hear enough of this, and you'll be deaf in no time. Rubber stopper things needed badly here to cover the ends of chair legs. Either that or cotton balls for your ears.

The women's bathroom line is notoriously long. Go to one on another level instead. Legs need to be stretched to sprint toward any open seats. Until you are seated, you need to be in "city parking" mentality at all times. If you don't know what that means, maybe you shouldn't be eating here at peak hours.

The negative things are minor, but could just make enough of a difference when it comes to star ratings.
author: Rona J.

description:
If you and your friends can't make a decision on where to eat, head to the food court for the variety. I've been here too many times to count (it's near my job), and I have yet to eat at half of these establishments.

It's extremely busy between noon and 1 p.m. and pretty pricey, but also strikingly clean for cafeteria atmosphere.

TIP: Instead of ordering a bottled water or soda, you can save $2-3 by asking for a glass of water at any of these places.
author: Matt N.

description: I didnt like at all.... the personal was not nice with the customers (especially with the old lady just before me..). The food was really disgusting.... First time and last time there
author: California G.

description:
Sure it's loud and noisy.  You feel like you're in one of those Asian malls. No, not like Pacific Mall, more like, in Seoul or HK. 
BUT...
Where else could you get a meal that includes Mac n Cheese from Bristol Farms, delectable Pumpkin Curry from Coriander, Asian Slaw from Mr. Hana, ending with one of those PB and Banana cookie thingies from Tom's,  all washed down one of those Supposedly Healthy Berry Tea drinks from That Tea Place?  
I LOVE THE WESTFIELD!!!!!!!!!
And after stuffing your face full of shit you shouldn't be eating, your fat ass doesn't even have to get out of the chair until you're good and ready because some nice person in a bow tie and white shirt comes to take your dirty tray away. Hence , you are privy to some interesting people watching (i.e. make mental caricatures of all those people around you) as you burp away your worries.
Ugh. Sucha glutton.
author: Joyhan S.

description:
Think ultra modern underground cavern of a cafeteria makes preppy shoppers feel sexier while they nurse their purchasing hangovers and gnaw on the bones of their second rate Korean BBQ short ribs. Now in a German accent, "Oh how dirty! I sink I vill take a baath."

Suck down neon green tea with beans in it, grub an over cooked plate of pasta, or wait in a really long line for a cream puff while having a wet dream about posing for a Crate and Barrel catalog. 

One extra star for opening stupid close to my apartment -- tripling the number of inexpensive places to consume calories in my ever so slowly gentrifying crack den of a neighborhood.
author: Brian S.

description:
This is by far THE BEST food court that I've ever been to.  It's not your typical food court which has the sbarro, hot dog on a stick, etc, etc...   This food court has restaurant-style food at decent prices.  They have selections ranging from sandwiches to Korean food, to Thai food, to seafood specialties! 

I opted for the Korean food.  For a little under $10 I got a huge plate which included rice, Korean noodles, steamed broccoli, and I chose the spicy chicken  (also had a bottle of water). I was pleased with the way the food tasted and was pleased with the quality of food (you seem to forget that you're eating in a shopping mall food court). 

Be careful if you choose to eat here on a weekend as it's usually packed and finding a place to sit is a little difficult... it is, afterall, a tourist spot! Also, be prepared to have bus boy service after you've finished your meal.  They serve your meals on real plates with real silverware (if you state that it's for here) and after you've finished your meal, people take away your plates and clean up your table... gotta love service!
author: Michelle N.

description:
Holy mackeral...THIS is what  a food court should be! I've never seen anything like it..in a mall, that is.
Every "stall" has food that smells and tastes great. There are no food chains that exist in here ( no East coast chains, at least). I heart the Thai iced tea... Although there isn't much else besides Asian cuisine...they all serve wine! Yes. WINE. At a "food court" in  a mall. And the mall staff cleans up after you. You don't have to go looking for the garbage...if you do, you'll get weird looks...like I did. Anywho, if you're not into shopping then at least hit the food court for a feel. If you're not into Asian food then go to the crepes/gelato stall! They make the crepes in front of you. Hope you enjoy!
author: Shirley L.

description:
Wow!  This is the nicest, quality food court I've ever encountered. For food court food, it's top notch.  They even use real silverware and plates.  They don't have a bunch of businesses crammed next to each other but quality before quantity, right?

Went to Ouththedoor and also got $5 fish n chips.

The only thing they can approve on is MORE seating.
author: Rich E.

description:
Damn you Westfield Food EMPORIUM. 

Whew! and to think I almost called you a foodcourt! 

You're the reason I'll never be satisfied with a foodcourt anywhere ever again. Thank you for partially ruining my existence. 

I'll be back. Finding a table on the weekends is a bitch!
author: Tushar V.

description:
After I got over the initial opening of the food "emporium" ("oooo, shiny!"), I realised this place isn't really that bad.

Never come here on a weekend! I mean, that's like common sense when it comes to malls. You'll end up sitting at the kiddie table with your beer and pizza if you don't heed your common sense. I speak from personal, awesome experience obviously.

Yeah, it's a little dim and what little lighting there is gives me a headache sometimes. Yeah, it can get really loud, so much so that if the adage "if it's too loud, you're too old" is right, I must be a billion years old.

Oh! But the cushion seats are comfy once you get over the possible sanitary issues and they have hand washing stations OUTSIDE the restroom. And it's not too difficult to find a glass of water around here. If you have kids, they have a "family room", whatever that is.

Food prices can put a dent in your wallet if you eat here every day. But it's easy to get to from the Mission garage through Bloomingdales and you can get here directly from BART/MUNI without stepping a foot outside.

Best part: you don't have to bus your tray. Makes me feel fancy.
author: Grace-Monday B.

description:
OMFG...who would've thought that a mall food court could be this good!  I love, love, LOVE everything about this section of the mall.  I came here on my last day in SF & I really wasn't expecting it to be so tasty & inexpensive.  I really didn't know where to begin or even what to select so  I walked around a bit & had lots of samples....more than once:) 

I settled for this Korean BBQ place where I got 3 huge pieces of short ribs, rice, noodles, & vegetables.  I couldn't finish it all so I had more than enough to eat on my flight (which ended up being my meal before my flight at the airport since my flight got delayed 2 hrs).  Anyway, the food was great & it only cost $8.95 before tax!!  

The one annoyance I had was with the huge crowds.  I was with a group of 11 so it was obviously hard trying to sit together.  We managed to collect chairs & tables while people bought food so by the time everyone had their food, we had sucessfully acquired 5 small tables  & 11 chairs.  (FYI...I do not recommend trying this if you're really hungry because it took awhile to make it happen).
author: Shelly C.

description:
Tons of choices
go to buckhorn...and get the tri tip salad, its rather yummy!

scoring a table is going to be drama, just accept this and try to find one.

and yes, you will be asked be a lot of people if you are using the chair...

once while waiting for the hubby to bring his food, (I should note this was around the holidays) i could not take a bite, because person after person interrupted me to ask if they could take the chair, one person went as far as to take the chair without asking! i was a bit pissy! like do you really think I am eating here all along, and did you not notice the 30 other people who just came up to me to ask for this damn chair!! oh it was awful and I could not wait to leave!!

dine at your own risk!
author: Deirdre P.

description:
Yeah its exactly what its called its a food "emporium" not a "court."

This place is IMPRESSIVE. 

It may have just been that I was there during the holdiay season but this place was buzzzzing, it was so packed that people were just eating where ever they could find a place to sit, even if that meant on the floor. 

The other reviews are right, you will not find your normal food court establishments here, no Sabarros, no Hot Dog on a Stick, no major fast food chains, no dollar deals. Your meal will probably not come cheap, but if you ever wanted that you could always walk down to their other food court which carries the typical mall fare.
author: kate r.

description:
OK my little secret is out. I HATE shopping at  the mall, but I like eating there. Kind creepy, I know. Just hear me out before you judge.

I am one of those people who needs to eat every hour or I get cranky. I tend to walk home from work from time to time with my guy and the mall is right on our way. By the time I make it all the way over to 5th and Mission, I am STARVING! So one day on our walk home, a moment of cranky hunger (my man likes to refer to it as something else that begins with a b) over came me. We just so happened to be in front of the mall. I was dragged quickly downstairs to get a quick bight to eat. 

I staggered up and down the court checking the food out with my tummy grumbling. All I can remember in my daze, was that to my surprise, there was some pretty decent looking food. We ended up eating at Coriander Thai and had a yellow curry and a veggie tofu dish. Pretty yum yum.

My blood sugar started to rise and I looked around the food court area now a sane and somewhat rational person. Whoa. I noticed people drinking wine and laughing like they would at a restaurant. How cool is that? I also noticed a gelato stand right smack in the middle of court. Even cooler. I looked at the tables surrounding us, not everyone had a shopping bag. This meant people were coming here like we were, just to eat. Interesting. It dawned on me then that this place was not a regular food court. We continued our walk home that evening with full bellies and lots of cheer. I had found a new drop-in-and-eat destination in the most unsuspecting location.

Now I regularly stop down here on my walks home with or without company. It's great. Of course I try to avoid the rest of the mall as much as possible. The other day I got sprayed with some obnoxious perfume on my walk out from dinner, but it is a small price to pay for some decent food.
author: Ali K.

description: I'm convinced they have everything you could possibly want at the food emporium. Not that this shocking but all of the choices  are organic and fresh. Hard to decide what to eat but something for everyone.
author: James Michael S.

description:
I tried the Seafood Tofu Soup (Soon) at the Korean food vendor.  It was such a huge bowl I thought I would only consume half of it.   Well, I consumed practically all of it - it was pretty darn good.  Comes with a bowl of rice, and cost less than $8 - Lunch special of the Day.

 Since most of the reviews mentioned Coriander, I'd thought the Tofu Stew was worth pointing out.

Best Food Mall court in Northern California for sure.
author: A. L.

description: Went to the Westfield Centre today and had lunch at the Buckhorn Grill.  It was just perfect!  I had the Roadhouse Salad and it was terrific.  It had lots of chicken breast (no cheapo dark meat) and other fresh ingredients like gorgonzola cheese, walnuts, and tomatoes.  My boyfriend had the tri-tip sandwich with fries and raved about it.  It came with a dipping sauce and tons of fries.  The service was quick too!  After shopping we returned and went to Beard Papa's (weird name!) for a cream puff.  Excellent!! There are so many choices at this food court that it's hard to pick where you want to eat, but all of the food looks fresh.  Bristol Farms has some great looking fresh turkey sandwiches and pizza.  I'll try there next time.  Definitely not your "Sbarro/Chick-fil-A/Burger King" food court.  This is top notch gourmet-type food which I guess, is why they call it an "emporium" instead of a food court! A+++
author: Sandra P.

description: Fresh vegetables but tri-tip was little rough. Good food for mall food
author: Yello I.

description:
food court! AHHHHHHHHH! so much variety! AHHHHHHHHH! i love it! pricey, but i would come here once in a while. maybe once or twice a year. definitely pricier than normal food courts though. however, the interior is pretty modern. 

VERY crowded, you would have to look around for a while for a seat. there might be a few times when you're so close to snatching a table, but a family and a couple of their slower walking kids would have snatched it by then. 
food after walking around in the mall. just what youll probably need.
author: Veranna N.

description:
The BEST food court ever. It's not like that fast food hot dog on a stick kind of shit. It's sit down restaurant quality food. My favorite is Coriander, the Thai food. RESTAURANT QUALITY. For two entrees, rice, thai tea all costs $13. Another favorite of mine was Teaz Me Tea, that had the BEST blended frozen mint tea smoothie with big chewy boba. This is no ordinary food court. And to satisfy your sweet tooth (as if the boba werent enough) the cream puff place has light sweet creamy melts in your mouth cream puffs. ahhhh. heaven.

i repeat: THis is no ordinary food court.
author: Laureen C.

description:
Food court seems OK, but freakishly busy.  We usually end up - ok, the few times we've been here - getting stuff at the Bristol Farms and carrying it over (because they have real fresh sushi). The food court, while busy, is pretty clean. I've always seen people around clearing and wiping tables off, clearing away food trays for you while you're still there but finished eating (nice!)  

That said, they do seem to have a pretty good variety of "upper end" food court places - not your typical stuff, but different is sometimes refreshing.
author: Jen D.

description: The spiral escalator is nice and the dome view is pretty.  7 story mall wow, and the food court has really good food. One of the better westfields i've been to for sure.
author: Johnny W.

description:
BE AWARE!!!

My purse just got stolen yesterday at the food emporium.  There seemed to be young girls who hangs out at this public place and grab your purse when you're not looking. They don't work alone, they would hand your purse to their friend so even when you recognize her, she will no longer has the evidence. 

I couldn't find even one security after I realized it happened. I had to go to Bloomingdale's and ask somebody to call a security. Just got to look out for yourself and be more cautious and suspicious.
author: Herdah S.

description: This place has a lot of nice stores and an awesome food court. Beware of the salesmen and saleswomen at the booths and their aggressive sales techniques though. It makes shopping very unpleasant.
author: Yoni D.

description:
my team at work and i go here every friday to try a new place each week. even though we know we will be back the following week, we can never decide what we want to eat! the food all looks & smells soooo delicious. 

this food emporium is completely amazing, i dont think anyone will get sick of it. there is sooo much to choose from. the environment is VERY nice, it's very clean (note: the sinks outside of restrooms! how convenient!) and there are a lot of workers there to keep it up to standard. it's well designed and the vendors are well chosen as they offer a good variety. it's very efficient with the "beepers". although a bit crowded, i still plan to frequent the food emporium as a place for takeaway.
author: Stella C.

description:
Is it sad that I often eat here when I'm downtown? The location is convenient, the prices are decent and I love the choices. Seating can be rough at peak hours, and somehow I always end up in that back right corner by the Japanese place, right next to the doors that all the employees go through. I love the smell of warm Pamolive as I munch on a chicken ceasar salad or the spicy green beans from the Thai place. 

The soups from Bristol Farms can hit the spot on cold days (or when you need a medium-sized snack, one that will make you feel fuller than you actually are). The bathrooms often have lines (but not usually for the dudes). If you feel particularly daring, try the family bathroom. I'm sure no one will think you're creepy.
author: Jared S.

description:
I've lived in Ohio, Portland and Vancouver, WA and they all have Westfields with food courts, but this blew me away.

Classy food, nice seating area and even the trays were stylish. While you do pay more for nicer food, it's a welcome sight when compared to the usual Auntie Anne's, McDonalds and other shops that populate most mall food courts. First time in my life I was excited about mall food!

Overall, it was a welcome rest from unhealthy eating and made me wish that more food courts were like this.
author: Jamila C.

description: Sorabol, the Korean restaurant, is DISGUSTING. The meet is chewy and fatty - some of the lowest quality meat I have ever had in a food court. The bulgogi was dripping with oil and in edible. I should have returned this awful food as I will need to eat lunch again. There is no excuse for a restaurant to serve this kind of food to paying customers.
author: Laurence S.

description:
I normally hate food courts (and indoor malls) but this place is so well designed and the choices are excellent!   

Did I just give a food court 5 stars?
author: J J.

description: If you go here you are bound to beaten up by their incompetent Gestoppo llike security guards.  I am a 49 yr young handicapped female.  I have GBS that keeps me in an electric wheelchair that dies.  I came up from bart into the food court where my boyfriend was to meet me.  The chair was dead.  SO i have just started to walk and decided to walk very slowly to the bathroom.  The toilet in the handicapped bathroom is always broken - full of tissue and god knows what.  So i went outside.  There were 2 ladies giving out free samples.  I only took one.  A security guard came and screamed at me because my shoes were not on.  I told her i had a wheelchair and she would not listen.  She refused to let me walk towards my wheelchair.  She shoved me because she wanted me to walk faster.  Finally, 4 more guards came.  They drag me through the food court screamimg for help and dragged me into tables and chairs.....
author: pilou o.

description: There are so many choices here.  I haven't had a chance to try all of the different restaurants in this food court, but so far, I haven't had a bad experience yet.  There's everything from American to Italian to Korean and just about everything in between.  The prices are OK and you can always do your shopping after having something in your belly.  Either that, or head home via BART.
author: Amy J.

description: A must visit while holiday shopping. Korean BBQ to Bristol Farms deli choices, this basement food court will have what you are looking for. A glass of fine wine will put you in a great mood before shelling out more dough at the mall. Be sure to save room for dessert.
author: Annie G.

description: This stuff is the bomb...Love the original flavor. It's a little pricy but great snack/breakfast food.
author: M M.

description:
This place is like glitter: fun to look at but bad for digestion. I'd rather eat at the bottom of Macy's where I can actually find something I want to eat.

FOOD: I've been there several times & had to walk round & round trying to find something I wanted to eat. No good deals to be found. 

~First time I wound up with Buckhorn Grill, which wasn't that great. 

~2nd time I did Sorabol Korean BBQ, which managed to make Korean BBQ untasteful. 

~Most ppl will disagree, but I'm not even that fond of Beard Papa--too light. I prefer the heft of the frozen cream puffs from Costco (after defrosting of course)!

~Walking past the baked goods section at Bristol Farms, we were overwhelmed by a stinky garbage smell when usually the smell of baked bread is what entices people to buy. I thought it might be the cheese? Anyways, ew.

~Everything sucks!

DECOR: It looks pretty, for sure, but it's all style, no substance. Even the banquettes are getting filthy. Disappointing.

BATHROOM: n/a

SERVICE: n/a

OVERALL: I'd rather eat at the bottom of Macy's, where I love the sushi & garlic mashed potatoes (not together, of course) from Wolfgang Puck Express.
author: miss b.

description:
Much like SFO, this food court is filled with a variety of local places - and just a few chains. Like Beard Papa but, you know, they get a free pass anywhere.

I really like the variety here. Burgers? Yep. Gourmet sausages? Yep. Italian, Thai, Vietnamese, American? Yep. Sushi? Indeed. And Bristol Farms, a full (small) grocery store? You got it.

Seating is plentiful and comfortable. It's really a pleasant place to eat, and it's nice that it's not just another silly food court.
author: Paul M.

description: Wide selections of delicious food, desserts and drinks. I love eating here; it's not your typical food court food. They offer high quality food selections e.g. Catch Ise (I love their Salmon BLT!), Sobabol, Buckhorn Grill, Cafe Bellini, Askew Grill, Bristol Farms, Beard Papa's & etc. Also, check out Witchcraft next to Bloomingdale's - they have very good grilled sandwiches that are not your typical ham and cheese!
author: linh d.

description: I was pretty hesitant when my friend suggested that we go to a food court for lunch for my only day in downtown SF. After some clarification and how she promised I'd be pleasantly surprised, I went along for the ride. Once we went down the escalator, I felt like a kid in a candy store! I walked around 3 times just to sink everything in and to try and narrow down my choices (do I want Thai... or Korean BBQ... no wait that pizza looks so good!... &@!%!)... After getting 2 platters to mix things up and a smoothy, I was satisfied. I will be definitely coming back here during my next trip!
author: Andrew Z.

description:
let's start with what is bad....

Malls, in my lifetime, will continue to  support and cater to what is already established, franchised, and trendy.... see the ed hardy shop on your right as you enter this multiplex of everything for the childless, maintly white, possibly cohabitating ( = extra grand or two for retain therapy), upper middle class of SF. ( no credit to the old school tattooers who generated a huge amount of classic flash, and yet aren't reaping the benefits of these classic designs being recreated in screening ink and rhinestones on american apparel( esque) t-shirts, at the tune of over $200 for a hoodie...

Straight up - yes, it caters to the demographic in which i place my living room. And there are so many aspects i love. That the dome is historic, the the architect for this building took care that from every level you could appreciate the dome, and yet at the top level, you can hang out underneath it... on couches.

MAD PROPS for the correct seats in the movie theatre..

MAD PROPS for promoting local cuisine in the food court

WAY TO set the standard for what a mall can be for....

my, select, demographic.

In a sense, i wish that i enjoyed the Westfield less. I feel like i'm letting  my punk history down.

And yet, as a woman in my thirties, i meet my friends here and feel pampered and comfortable.

So when do i gain weight and start fucking the poolboy? ( or pool trannie, i guess, i mean, we ARE living in SF... right ?)
author: Domini A.

description:
The food selection in the old Emporium is great, but I just wanted to Yelp the busers and security guards that patrol the area and give them their credit  for actually caring about the people who shop there even though half  of them (present writer excluded) are "douche-bags." 

One of the many security guards approached my friend who had her bag hanging from the back of her chair.  At first we thought he was hitting on her but then he told her, "ma'am its not a good idea to put your belongings there... there have been a lot of thefts."  

I was impressed by the service.  As we were leaving, my friend commented on the huge mounds of gellato that where on display, and how they were made.  The buser over heard her question and was willing to ask the workers at the gelato place how they made the mounds.  Even though we declined his offer to  ask the workers it made us laugh that they would even make the effort. 

I expect customer service like that at places like the Ritz or the Four Seasons, but not at a food court. I just wanted to say thanks and I am a fan of this food court or to use a dumb-ass euphemism: "In-mall Dining Cuisine!"
author: Nino P.

description:
I'm not a mall rat and generally-speaking I avoid them as I do unmarked freeway exits and the mid west in general. My experience with malls tends to involve headaches and parking lot exiting difficulties that have "city folk" written all over them and which bear more resemblance to that first demerit we all earned while getting out of the DMV back at the age of sixteen. In itself a cruel and discombobulating rite of passage that should mark the only time you'll find an adult in uniform in the passenger seat, with a clipboard and an unmistakeably nervous demeanor. 

I dont know if there's parking at this place though I imagine if there is it's more of the sort sporting only one way in and one way out, each perilously close to the other. 

I take the muni which rocks, and which also involves a uniformed adult up front, though hopefully sans clipboard. I don't think there's a passenger seat up there. 

The mall itself, what's left for it here, is splendid urban capitalism at its shiniest. If you can't find what you're looking for here, you need to hit one of the many optometrists within. The cupola offers a great place to hang out and people watch. And the basement has a great selection of foods. Including that inaptly and ineptly named cream puff shop, Beard Mama. Oops. Beard Papa. Heck, maybe it's a family thing.
author: adrian c.

description:
Like the rest of the Westfield center, this place has got great design and is filled with people who do not know/do anything else than window shopping.
The franchise restaurants are on the high end and offer great food, you won't find your typical yucky mall court food here.
And it's probably the most crowded area of the mall: finally somewhere trendy teens can afford spending money other than on buying stickers at Hollister so they feel good about it and can fall asleep at night after watching the OC with a satisfied grin on their face for being so complete in their life.

Ah and watch out for your belongings, one of my friends got her purse stolen there which seemed like a sad routine for security.
author: Damien J.

description: Great place to get upscale fast food. Also one of the only malls that have bussers to bus your food for you. Love to eat Korean food at Sorabol...Get a lot of food for the price you pay and very tasty.
author: Karen M.

description:
I would give it 5 stars, but:
-if you're not from the area, you have to commute by bart, which is $9.90 from where I board.  that is, if you don't drive.
-food court is pretty expensive.
-super croweded.

The GOOD:
+Zomg, such a breath of fresh air considering the malls I'm used to going to (Newpark, Southland...lol).
+Sprial escalators! AMAZINGGGG! (:
+Multiple elevators!
+A bunchhhhh of stores. Three stories, I believe. All kinds of stores with names I've never heard of before.
+The people who clean up in the foodcourt wear ties!! WHAAAT!?
+Right next to Powell St. Bart.

I wanna go back, and actually buy things other than food. Lol.
author: Ava A.

description: It's like a tiny bit of Singapore here in good ol' Frisco! And what variety, and you can walk around and check it all out and talk with people waiting to buy food and find out why they like it and maybe you'll like it... Wonderful, fresh, inexpensive food, clean surroundings, fast paced (slower on 4th floor) and usually crowded. Welcome to San Francisco!
author: William M.

description: When you think about mall food courts you think fast food - burgers, pizza and the like - not here! Top notch eaterys - all served on real plates, glasses and silverware! And you don't clean up after yourself - they have attendants all over the place to clean and remove your place setting!
author: Peter S.

description: Wide selection of food ! Korean,Mexican, American, Italian, Sandwiches, Pizza,Sushi etc. I always don't know where to eat at when I'm here because they all look so good. The best food I had here was  Sorabol Korean BBQ & Asian Noodles, a lotta food, good korean food! If youre ever in for asian food, you gotta try it.
author: Maddie O.

description:
In the food court of my hometown mall, we had things like Hot Dog on a Stick, Mrs. Field's cookies, and Panda Express. 

The Westfield Food Court (oh, excuse me, EMPORIUM) is another experience all together. Beard Papa? Asquew Grill? Gourmet Mexican food? Whoa.

The prices here definitely reflect the "food court plus" atmosphere, but it's a great place to stop for a bite when you're shopping downtown.
author: Vandana M.

description:
People - you're in a mall! The BK Lounge is a 1/2 away, if you're missing the ambiance of a traditional food court. Anyway, it's better than what you get in any airport in the US, and convenient to boot. Which, I'm guessing,  is their main goal - fast food, fast $$$.

Why 5 stars? It works for me. The reviews of food don't make sense to me, 'cause it ain't date/business/family event dining venues. It's 'I gotta' get my ass back to work in a hurry' food.
author: Rene D.

description:
I never thought I'd be promoting a mall while living in SF.  That was, until I found this spot.

Sure, it is expensive, but so is everything else in this city.

The Bloomingdales is absolutely huge and great for getting gifts for my girlfriend.  I like the other stores as well, a mix of ultra-trendy to punk stores.  The jewelry stores are very fun to window shop as well.

I haven't used the spa before, but have heard its very nice....may get my girlfriend a gift there.

I love the movie theatre, and the seat comfort puts the Metreon to shame.  

Bristol Farms has helped to redefine nice store shopping in the city and is a pleasant alternative to Whole Foods.

The food court is often too crowded, but has a great selection (not your typical mall food court with hot dog on a stick).  I can get a great burger, sandwich, salad, Thai, Vietnamese, Chinese, Korean, Mexican, crepes, smoothies, etc.  I love it.  I can actually walk there from my place to grab dinner too if I want something tasty, don't feel like cooking and don't want to spend $100 at a local restaurant.

Finally, you've got to check out the dome.  Its the old dome/skylight from the Emporium that closed down and this really pleasantly integrates historical elegance and modern luxury.

Also, this mall is a hop, skip and a jump from Union Square, for even more shopping and restaurants.

Hands down, five stars!!!
author: Aaron M.

description: This place is great if you can't decide what to eat...they are definitely much better than any other food court, thats why you pay the prices.  I like the thai food place which has the yellow curry chicken with rice, or the sweet basil chicken with rice.  The korean food place is good too, but they give you too much food, and I think their marinade on their meats are too sweet.  Catch has a good salmon risotto and seafood soup.
author: Amy A.

description:
I work in front of the Westfield Centre.

Once in a while I make it to the food court for overpriced lunches on china plates. 

I didn't like Coriander very much.  Their pumpkin curry was mediocre. 

But I usually head to Askew because their salads are good and filling.  Not a fan of their meat skewers, but their veggie one rocks.
author: Laura G.

description:
It's a beautiful, lovely...food court.  And that kind of makes my mental wiring short-circuit a little.  Mall food courts should always be the same, involving things like Sbarro, even in San Francisco.  I thought they were supposed to give you a sense of consistency in this world.  But Westfield has to go and try to be original in the food court world, and I'm not sure how I feel about that.  
I've eaten here a few times because I used to go to the SFSU campus a few floors above.  Food is average and overpriced.  $9 for a burrito?  Come on.  It's in a food court.
author: Lego S.

description:
heres a place that WOWed me like there was no tomorrow. my friend and i were here after the remodel and she was telling me that i needed to check out the food court. i was like 'what the hell? whats so special?' and then i went down there and i was like HOLY CRAP!!! every step i took revealed something more and more. this place was not only made to look especially nice, but all the restaurants here are nothing like you've ever seen (more or less) definitely not your typical panda express, and sbarro stuff but it had japanese, korean, thai, steak and among other things. they use REAL plates and give you REAL silverware! after you're done eating, no need to take ur plate in, they have bussers to bus tables! what kind of crazy is this?!?! 

every one of my friends i've brought here have had the same reactions as me. at first they're like 'really? a food court?' then when they see it its like 'wow... wow.. wow'

indeed it is.. wow
author: edward k.

description:
This food court in the expanded S.F. Shopping Centre is the best shopping mall food court I've ever encountered. The selection is incredible, there are several higher-end establishments that serve very good food, and it even looks snazzy. 

Notable spots include: Out the Door (a mini and way cheaper Slanted Door), 'Wichcraft, a Sorabol that actually serves decent-tasting Korean food, San Francisco Soup Company, Buckhorn Grill, Mr. Hana, Andale, and Beard Papa. Not to mention the Bristol Farms (yes, I know it's non-union) and Peets Coffee.  

Far and away better than your average food court.  It does get very packed and crowded and it is often difficult to find an empty seat during peak meal times. Still, the Food Emporium is definitely worth stopping by to get some good ass grub.
author: Jenny K.

description:
This is the nicest, most exclusive food court I've ever seen. No fast food, no junk. everything's organic and/or gourmet. Pretty cool, but not if you're in the mood for a burger and shake or a warm oozy pretzel.

The Thai place is pretty good, and cheap: 2 items for like 10 bucks. And the servings are ample enough that you could share with a friend if you're looking for a light meal (as to fit into all those nice clothes upstairs in Bloomies).
author: Christy M.

description:
As my review of the Shopping Centre itself stated stay out of this side of the SF Shopping Centre as much as you can, but cross over for the food because its amazing. The selection is great and you don't have to settle for panda express, steak escape, or rubio's anymore you can finally have some better more upscale food in a shopping mall. 

The best part is of course the Beard Papa's. Soo good.
author: Ali L.

description: What a food court! There are so many choices and not enough time or stomach space. My girls and I wanted variety for lunch and we decided to take a bus ride over here. The three of us went our separate ways, my cuz had the Thai place, my friend the Mexican and I had American fare. We were all pleased, getting a table took a bit of maneuvering but we ended up with a nice spot to gossip and people watch. This place is great and we'll be coming back for more. Oh and for dessert we all indulged in some beard pappa, yum.
author: La C.

description:
This food court will redefine your expectations of "mall food."

Actually, every other mall should pay attention.  This not-so-little court has a sample of some San Francisco favorites.  You won't find your Wendy's, MacDo's, or any of your typical fast food mall fare here.  The food here is not a punishment, but a treat.

From Asqew Grill, Out The Door, Coriander , to Bistro Burger you can treat yourself to some pretty good eats.  This is a great place to take and seat a large group of friends, if you're in the area.  Everybody can scatter and get what they want.

It's hard to leave without at least sampling Beard Papa's flavor of the day, or some gelato from one of Melt Gelato & Crepe Cafe's many flavors.

Four stars from convenience, and good food!
author: Shea G.

description:
3.5 stars.

For a mall food court, this is good selection of mostly high-quality places. 

Cons:
-It's overpriced. Yes, I know it's in a mall. That doesn't mean that I want to pay $11.50 for lunch. 
-Few vegan options, and no really, really good ones--unless we count the garlic fries at that burger bistro. That's hardly a meal, though. And yes, since this place is trying to be a cut above yer average mall food court, i DO expect vegan options.
-It's in a mall. That means that you get the dirty little tables, noise and long lines you would elsewhere.

The bathrooms are clean, though.
author: Ramon E.

description:
It's a big and beautiful mall, but I could not find a nice pair of white sneakers. Also the male selection at Bloomingdale and Nordstrom SUCKS!

My favorite thing about this mall is the relaxation area on the top floor and that yummy chocolate store.
author: Chatree T.

description:
Janice says-  Finally we're catching up:  a mall with a market and good food choices in the food court downstairs just like the malls in Asia 10 yrs ago.  Anyways, I like the food court better than the mall.  I mean at least I can afford a sandwhich since I can't afford anything else at the retail stores!  

props:
-lots of selection obviously and tastes good.
-lots of people cleaning up and nice (in a food court?!!)
-more or less well orgainized.

cons:
-hard to find a seat
-$$$
author: Janice's A.

description:
(around 11:30am otherwise known as when my stomach starts to eat itself)

Me: "LUNCH??"
Friend: "where?"
Me: "Oh baby, KOREAN BBQ!!"


. . . when I'm looking to procrastinate from work, me and my buddy go here to get decent korean bbq or my favorite cellulite-maker, Bearded Papa. There's lots of seating, if you don't mind sharing a long table with other touristy/workywork people and having them stare intently at you when you're having a private conversation and interjecting "Oh that's happened to me to! *giggle*"

Pluses: KOREAN bbq, Bearded Papa, pretty chairs/decor, lots of choice

Minuses: I broke the butter knife cutting the tri-tip from one of the places .
author: Glamorous D.

description:
I can move in there today!!  We loved the food court so much that my friend and I were there every day for lunch and sometimes dinner while we were visiting SF for 4 days for work.  

Great service, wonderful choice of food, and huge seating areas that are clean and well attended.   I'm writing my local LA Westfield begging to bring the same food court to my hood!!
author: Yoko M.

description:
PROS:

Variety of restaurants....take your pick

There are employees cleaning tables and trays promptly when you leave

Service is quick

Sometimes people watching can be fun.

CONS:

Full of people.....you can barely walk

The food doesn't seem too appealing

Prices are outrageous

NEVER eat at Asqew. Please read my review on this horrendous place.

http://www.yelp.com/biz/asqew-grill-san-francisco-6#hrid:d9DkEPsiKOyt41mUbljCRw

Are you old enough to remember the old Emporium -Capwell from back in the days? Well, I have. I am glad that they kept the original arch/dome in front of Market Street, It brings back memories. The place is breathtaking for me. The shops are certainly has changed  for the better. Theres a movie theater inside as well. I believe a multi-plex. Food court on the lower level, super market...Good God!
The Westfield is connected to the SF Centre. Close to Bart, and Muni.
Go check it out if you have done so yet.
author: Smooth R.

description:
I'm usually an everything eater, even if I don't really like it, I'll just eat it and think of something else.. But the food here is just not for me. The food is tasteless or just gross. The whole place stinks, the tables are dirty and there are way too many people. 
I'd rather skip dinner than going here...
author: Helen D.

description: One of the nicest food courts I've been to.  There's something here for everyone: American to Italian to Korean foods, plus desserts and Bristol Farms.  Most of the restaurants are chains, but they're nicer than your typical mall chain -- no Sbarro or Hot Dog on a Stick here.  There are lots of places to sit but it can be hard to find a seat during peak hours as it can get crowded.  Workers usually come around often to bus tables.
author: Arthur C.

description: LOVED this place the first time I wandered in to it on Powell Street muni/bart station. There is so much to chose from and all of the eateries are a bit upscale. Ive probably tried something at every restaurant. The downside however is this place can get packed and during the lunch rush it can be difficult to find seating especially if you are carrying around a tray of food.
author: Julian I.

description:
this food court is very good....not like the normal ones we find in all the malls. I enjoy the shopping there too.

time to get hit the mall again.
author: rasaka s.

description:
The best food court I've ever been too. Period. High quality local chains, make this 3 steps up from the Sbarro/Panda Express/Subways/Burger Kings you see in every mall in the country. The mall itself is nice but a  little too trendy and high end for me, but I love good food and will pay a little bit more for it. It gets quite crowded but there's plenty of seating throughout this basement level emporium. Bristol Farms is down there too and you can get even more food to eat there or take out. Asqew, Buckhorn, Pasta Moto, SFO Soup and Bistro Burger are top notch. There's a seafood place I need to try next time. They have a great bakery with real fresh scones, brownies and cookies.

The clincher for the 5 star rating is the use of regular plastic plates and real silverware. Not as much paper and plastic waste. I hope not too many forks and knifes are swiped from there.
author: Jim K.

description:
It's expensive. It's crowded. It's also what my friend calls "The Food Court of God." 

What makes it so godly is the wide selection of non-chain food restaurants. They aren't all spectacular, but it's certainly unique and certainly better than nearly any food court you will probably find anywhere. If you go down to the other end, you can find more chain restaurants. Don't be dissuaded by this- they have one of the only two Rubio's (with crack-laced chipotle salsa) in SF.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Well, they have tons and tons of stores..... several floors......but it's always crowded.

I haven't just wandered around everywhere yet, but it's so big I could totally get lost.
author: Stacy M.

description:
The food is definitely not your normal food court food.  It actually bummed my brother out that there wasn't a Hot Dog on a Stick.  Whatever.  Lots of choices for decent prices.  Trying to get a seat was a whole other issue.  The place was crazy packed with people and we had to hover around groups that looked like they were almost done.

They did have lots of staff around cleaning up the moment people did abandon a spot - so snaps for that.  Had trouble finding food that my six year old niece would eat.  She's one of the picky eaters.  Luckily they did have a pizza place but nothing to buy by the slice.  You had to order and get a buzzer.

I had a combo plate from the Thai food place that was great.  Lots of food and fairly good for eight bucks.  If your in a pinch and in the area, not a bad place for a decent lunch.
author: Dawn S.

description:
Yum yum is the gelato, also the crepes.  Don't hate on Bristol Farms.  They bring good things to good people.  10 points for the speedy clean up crew, since it is usually hard to find a table.  

One guy sat down at the table next to me while I was waiting for my friends.  He then informed me he didn't want to sit next to me, since I had a "bad aura".  He left, my friends arrived, we ate.  A few minutes later he came back, apologizing, saying he was "just PMSing".  I said I understand, it happens to me too.
author: Ariana N.

description:
As far as food courts go... this is just pretty damned amazing. 

I dont know, but when I was told that we were going to a food court, suddenly I just lost my appetite. Visions of General Tsos chicken under heat lamps and bad pizza were called to mind, while the sound of children running around with hot dogs on a stick echoed through my mind. *shudder*

This was nothing like that... very modern looking, open space, and a variety of food that... well, as compared to the food court in my mind... that I actually wanted to eat. Everything from Korean to Mexican, from Thai to Salads. 

When we were in a pinch for time (headed out drinking, priorities here, you know), we needed to get something in our stomachs (one must be responsible, after all) and needed to appease seven diners (though, luckily none of them are picky). Thus, one of us recommended the food court (and was prepared for the reeling looks of disgust on our faces, and to talk us off the ledge (or onto the escalator, as it were)). 

Give it a shot...  its a good step up from Food Court food... I think I might even head back there for lunch today (the Thai place is calling to me)
author: Jordan Y.

description:
Had food from Bistro Burger: Great! Loved the variety of vegetarian burgers.
Had food from Pasta Moto, also nice, but way to much garlic in the Penne Pomodoro. That says a lot coming from me, because I really adore garlic. But I think they burnt the garlic as there was a bitterness to the taste and also my boyfriend could smell the garlic from my mouth while sitting at the other side of the table. Bit embarrassing this time, usually I don't care if I smell like garlic, but this time it was a bit TOO extreme. My boyfriend enjoyed the Panino Caprese, but we thought it was weird that you get salad and POTATO CHIPS with the sandwich. But still, good food.
We also went to the Out the Door restaurant since we couldn't order noodle soup to go. Weird. Our waiter was helpful and friendly. My boyfriend enjoyed his chicken, not very special though, and I found my vegetarian noodle soup quite bland, definitely not going back it's way too expensive.
Also had a mint choc chip ice cream at Melt which was nice.

Overall the food court at the Westfield is clean and most eateries aren't expensive but do have tasty food. So 3.5 stars.
author: Bekkah R.

description:
WOW! This place blew me away! We started our mini vacation here by grabbing a coffee and waiting for our room to be available. We couldn't believe the amount of people at the food court! This was the only downside of this food court. We pretty much had to fight for our seats. If you do not like crowded places this is not the place for you!!!!

They had all types of food choices, Soup and salad, gourmet burgers, fresh japanese, Hot dogs, Vegetarian, Crepes, Thai, bbq, Mexican and a few others I can't recall. 

So I had the Japanese and the hubby had the bbq. 

The japanese food was amazing for just being food court food. I got the teryaki chicken with rice and stir fry veggies. YUM.

Hubby got a Tri-tip sandwich and onion rings. YUMMY!

So if you want to kill some time and do some shopping this mall is awesome, the food court was amazing and its really clean. Also you can catch the MUNI and BART right off the food court so that was awesome! We had lunch on our way out of town and grabbed the bart back to SFO!
author: Jamie B.

description: There are a lot of great places to eat here if you happen to be shopping at the Westfield Mall and just don't feel like leaving the mall for lunch or dinner. I usually go to Bristol Farms and buy one of their prepackaged Salads, Turkey Rolls, or a Falafel Sandwich. They're  not actually cheap, but the good quality and convenience is worth it. I also sometimes go to Sorobal and order the Korean BBQ Chicken with Noodles. It's kind of a pain when looking for a table when it gets really busy--that's why it is best to try not to eat there at the peak of lunch or dinner or else you may find yourself spending as much time running around looking for a table as you will eating your meal. Also, the restrooms have attendants and have those great efficient Dyson Air Blade Hand Dryers--no more wet floors to slip on.
author: Robert T.

description: I like their big mixed salad that includes guacamole, sour cream, meat, lettuce all in a crispy shell. The other Mexican stall sells a better version though. Cost was about $13 but well worth it. I could eat about 3/4th of it so I can't share but I cant finish it either.
author: Keit K.

description: The best fast food-dine-in style place around with good quality food!!.. Price is high but if you were to buy this kind of food at an actual dine-in restaurant, then you would be paying double on what it is.
author: Jon T.

description: This is probably the most diverse food court I've seen...ever. It's got almost every single type of food you could want on the bottom floor. It gets pretty crowded around lunch time, but it's still a great place to stop for lunch.
author: Eugene H.

description: Oh yeah, it is one of the best places to dine. Look at the prices too. $2.50 for an Eclair, $9.00 for a small bowl of Korean BBQ, $9 per pound for fried rice and chinese food from Bristol farm, etc., Overpriced fast food court in San Francisco.
author: Dennis W.

description:
How sad that Westfield has turned SF into just another big city maul... I've seen the same stores in Chicago, NY and all over the country - none of these chains creates a sense of place or really reflects the uniqueness of San Francisco.

The food court is really nice and the movie theatre is all plushed out with the latest mod-cons (Like LEGROOM!)

I'm glad they kept the dome but everything else is just too generic...
author: Quartknee K.

description: This mall food court is probably one of the nicest and most luxurious of mall food courts I've seen in California. Lots of seating, lots of food selections, I'd recommend dropping by for lunch or just to check out when cruising around Wesfield mall in SF.
author: Uland L.

description: I come here more often then i like to admit, a food court?? srssly you may say, but this one is a bit more upscale. Lots of great options like Out The Door, Coriander, Korean BBQ, Japanese bowls, pasta, buckhorn, beard papas, oh my!   Tons of seating as you would expect from a food court but what is nice, is that you can get what you want and your friends can as well.  All the while you can share a table. Worth a visit to the westfield to have some food court fun!  afterwards you can go shopping to work off those lbs.
author: Ka C.

description: Yeah, it doesn't have Auntie Anne's, Orange Julius, Cinnabon or Mrs Fields, so what exactly is this food court good for? If I wanted to eat real food, I would not be at the mall.
author: Maria D.

description: Expensive and people don't throw away their trash after they are done.  Too much people and its nice.  Rather go to Jack in the Box on Mission near 4th st.
author: John F.

description: This food court is the bomb! It doesn't really look like your typical food court. The place looks really trendy and sophisticated. The variety of food here is more upscale than other food courts that I've been to. I ordered from the Coriander Gourmet Thai and Sorabol Korean BBQ & Asian Noodles. Both place tasted awesome and their prices were not bad- about $10 for a combo plate at each place. I would definitely come here again. Next time I will try the gelato at the Melt Gelato & Crepe Cafe. Seatings could be kinda hard to find if it's busy. If you come here in a large group, good luck with finding a table to fit all of ya'll.
author: Kim N.

description: I can't imagine a food court getting much better than this one. I mean, how can you really judge it outside of variety, prices and seating? It has the most selection I've ever seen and I've been to A LOT of malls...a lot, a lot; nothing compares. The prices are reasonable, I wouldn't go as far as to say they were cheap but really, outside of Taco Bell, what's considered cheap anymore? I'm paying $7 for a cup of soup now for peets sake. Lastly, there is plenty of seating. Even on a Saturday I've never had any problems finding a place to rest my tired, shopped out feet.
author: Julia N.

description: Great high end food court when traveling in a group and not sure where to eat in the area. They have wide selections for everyone. They don't have your typical food chains like McDonald's, but something a little more expensive and fancier.  It has a nice clean feel to it since they use real silverware and they're all the same for all locations in the court. They have people coming around to pick up after you so you don't need to throw your garbage away like normal food courts.
author: Annie D.

description: Definitely not your typical food court. For a food court, this place sure gives you some great options. There are some over-priced stores, but some of them come with good quality food and large portions (see my review of Sorabol in this food court). We like Sorabol's korean food, Corriander Thai's thai iced tea, and Beard Papa's cream puff.
author: Chris Y.

description: I'm especially fond of the salad bar at Bristol Farms, but love that the food court caters to all different tastes: salty, sweet, and fried!  You can't beat the variety of quality food choices plus there isn't an additional 20% tip tacked onto the prices of a regular restaurant.  I didn't realize there are alcohol options too, so I will need to seek that out next time.
author: catherine g.

description: If we're downtown and it's time to eat, I'd say half the time we end up here.  Why?  Because they have a great selection of places with decent prices and a reasonably nice atmosphere, for a food court.
author: Dan S.

description:
i have never been to a food court, er, i mean emporium, where they serve alcohol.  it's amazing.  now, i'm not a lush lush, but i do like my wine.  and the meals here are worthy of being had with wine (and not an O.E. in a paperbag like other, less sophisticated food courts).  

however, most of the restaurants close at 9 which is a bummer if you are going to see a late movie.  and i have to take off one star for the possibility that i might drink first then shop while lacking all inhibitions and spending way too much money at bloomies.
author: Jessica W.

description: Any food court that does not have a Panda Express, Nathan's Hot Dogs, Cinnabon, Sbarro or Taco Bell gets 5 stars from me!
author: Marina T.

description: For the most part, I avoid the greasy, overcrowded, calorie laden crap they serve at malls.  The smell of sbarros next to some Japanese teriyaki   joint literally makes my stomach churn.  Especially when the smell of over-sugared 3yr olds are thrown in the mix.  But one day I found myself in need of substance after a long afternoon of working out my credit card, and decided to descend the escalator into the underworld.  And to my surprise I discovered a smrgsbord of delectable cuisines.  So I did it...I gave the "food court" a shot...and you know what....if was good! Sure the price is a little high...But after spending $350.00 on an amazing pair of Marc Jacobs, 4 inch, peep toe heels, what's another $10 for a great salad?    After all...shopping takes alot out of a girl!
author: Charisse F.
