description: Don't recall seeing a better food court with richer options. And they have people cleaning up your trays & tables during and after!
author: Elaine H.

description: Despite the basement food court ambience, a delightful choice for a casual meal. So many choices, and some are exotic: Pad Thai, kimchee, hummus, grilled salmon and salad, gelato - find it all here. This food mall is noisier but better-lit and more active than the much smaller one in the Metreon across the street. Both have nice, friendly staff, though. Excellent value for the money, and who doesn't value that, these days?
author: Cecily B.

description:
Wow..some of the below reviews about this food court are hilarious (in an I'm laughing AT YOU sorta way).   

I didn't know that UNTASTEFUL was a word!  haha...
the spellizations and grammaticizing is excellentable.

OKAY..back to the place.

THE AMENITIES.
The food court  was very clean, very nicely furnished and has a high end contemporary feel.  Lots of wooden chairs, grey metals, etc.

MISCELLANEOUS OBSERVATIONS
Did no one else smell the STRONG WHIFF of synthetic sweet/sour sauce smell??   My friends and I could smell that from all the way inside Bloomingdales while walking past the women's bag section.   It was so strong..it almost made us turn around and NOT go into the food court.

The cleaning staff around the food court were attentive and for the most part really nice.  Except for the guys toting out the big rolling  trash bins.  Those guys were from the wrong side of the hood rehabilitation program, and were mouthing off at patrons "Get the hell out of the way...man!..Damn!" as they carted their trash bins through.   Their manager seemed to look the other way.    I'm not so sure how long that will last before getting addressed.

THE PEOPLE (*sigh)
At the same time, if I had to encounter the patrons like the ones at this food court, I'd probably be yelling like those trash guys were too.  (Not to condone what they did..but I UNDERSTAND...=) )

SNOOTY SNOOTY SNOOTY.  

Sprinkled all over the footcourt was like a casting call for all 
the young girls who wanted to be on the show Laguna beach.

Lots of Abercrombie Blondes, and the token azn who could look very slender chic, or could be lumbering w/turnip like ankles.  Depends on which food they were eating =)

Lots of big sunglasses, tight jeans, rhinestones, and hoop earrings.
Oh and lots of purses w/Coach brand "C's" plastered all over.  Just spells CLASS.

Lots of blazer wearing sneaker heads w/a skull cap if you're hip hop..or spikey hair if you're not.  Holla if you hear meh!

People sit, and look at or THROUGH each other..if you will..in a very pretentious way..as to check what other people are doing...but make a futile attempt at faking it =)   

Amidst the faking funk, you'll find some upscale burger joints, salads, pastas, etc.

The most popular restaurants seemed to be Sorabol (the sweet/sour version of korean food..hence the popularity)..  Barebecue'd meats, sugary sauce w/brocooli and some rice.   Yum.

Coriander Thai food (see..Sorabol)...Some of the smells there though..yikes..putrid.

and Buckhorn.   Buckhorn was the fast food version of an awesome steakhouse chain up in the Sacramento area.    The meats are still very good here, and if you want to sit and oogle the cute laguna beach patrons..you'll find them here.

The foods around the foodcourt are more upscale than a regular run of the mill foodcourt w/corndogs etc....but you also pay for the upscaling.  Meals are 10 dollars minimum (that's w/drinks included)..which people happily pay ..for the ambience.

Check out the center aisle's gelato shop.  The ice cream is displayed in giant rotund containers and neately pack into thimble sized cups for 3 bucks a pop.

Pricey mall food, pricey ambience, overly blatant patrons fronting to the extreme.   But hey..maybe that's what you want??

If you drop 800 bucks on a ready made suit in Bloomingdales, or get a 800 dollar handbag there...what's another 20-30 for lunch?
author: Michael L.

description: I liked the idea of them making you a salad with your burrito and the presentation was great. However when I sat down to enjoy luch I picked up the burrito and it was covered in green oil from what ever was on the salad. then i take a bite and it not the meat or beans that I orderd WTF
author: Donyell T.

description: Ken and I played hooky on a work day. Our first time to walk through the new Westfield SF Shopping Centre Food Court. It was absolutely breathtaking. kinda.sorta.notreally. But seriously, it was an awesome experience to walk around and look at different menus. It was busy on a Monday afternoon. It was definitely a treat, granted I had never gotten the chance to go walk around here while I was working in the FiDi. I wished I had sooner.
author: Mika D.

description:
OK - I love the food court here at Wesfield.  Still love it now, though I had a really bad experience at Corriander - the Thai place.  After finished shooping and feeling tired I wanted to go home, but thought I'd stop by at Corriander.  This was probably my fourth time going there.  I got the usual Chicken Basil dish with rise, eggroll and Thai ice tea.  This time I decided to take it to go.  I couldn't wait to eat when I got home.  After few bites, I realized myself kept chewing, chewing and chewing but the thing I chewed I thought was chicken, it just wont break away in my mouth.  I was curious I spit it out and examined what I was chewing.....until...then I realized...it wasn't chicken...or bone...or plastic that maybe somehow got in the food...but what I was chewing was......"A huge frieking french manicure fingernai!!!!!!!"  I was grossed out, I felt sick right away and I threw up big time.  I was feeling sick with the thought that i was chewing a human being's fingernail....someone's fingernail....that maybe belong to the cook?   That was pretty DAMN GROSS!!  I was thinking going to them and tell them what I ate and that it was unacceptable, but it was always late in the night - around 9 pm, so I decided to just forget it and not think about it 'cause it makes me feel sick everytime the thought of me chewing someone else's fingernails makes me wanna throw up and I did many times.
So, from then on, I decided not to go to back to Corriander.  It's too bad because the food was good, but after that point on, I don't think I can ever eat there again -I just think that whoever it is the cook that prepare the food, they should probably wear gloves.  I am a health freak - now I trust only my own cook/caterer who prepares my daily food.
author: Jasmijn L.

description: 2.5 stars. Been here 4 times, and each time I tried something from a different stand/stall? I've tried the Soup, Thai, Korean, and Mexican. Not the best quality in food but had a better selection than your regular everyday mall food court. It does get overly crowded and the prices are much higher than you would expect for fast food at the mall. 2.5 stars for the concept and the variety of the selection.
author: Em T.

description: Yes, I am giving it a 5 star. The food might not be restaurant quality, but this is truly the best out there, a five start food court compare to other food courts. The decor and the food is unarguably the best I have seen in a food court. I guess that is why they named it food emporium.
author: Jose K.

description: Coriander Gourmet rocks for mall Thai food!  Though slightly overpriced, they actually give generous portion sizes and the quality is very decent.  I ordered rice w/eggplant and tofu for myself and the noodles w/chicken for my friend, and we both were very happy with how everything tasted.  Though the food court looks great, the noise and crowds are not my scene.  I say this is a solid take-out joint, esp. if you went shopping and want to grab something to go that's quick and on the way to BART.
author: Swetha G.

description:
im wondering why as a whole this place has such high ratings (4-5 stars) but when i look up individual restaurants they are mostly, if not all, 2-3 star average places? 

ive tried enough places in this "food emporium" (sorabol, coriander, andale, melt, buckhorn grill, and that sandwich place next to sorabols) that i think i can safely say that this place is a collection of overpriced food masked in a "fancy food court" facade. yes the presentation was good, yes the quality of the food is fresher than say, taco bell or mcdonalds...but for like 5 times the price it better be better.  I think people are better off going to places that serve good thai food (king of thai) elsewhere than a place where they serve meh thai food but if everyone wants something different and cant agree, then yes this place would be ideal.  but just seriously be blown away by the prices. NOT cheap.
author: Peggy W.

description:
This posh food emporium won this out-of-towner over. Best food court in America, folks. Classy, modern decor + excellent food + tons of vendors to choose from = win, win for me! You San Francisco people disgust me over how much you take for granted here in this city! Food court, schmoocourt, this place is gooooooood. If I had wanted a Taco Bell, Sbarros, and other cheap eateries, I'd be in Milpitas.
My local friend introduced it to me since we were 
a) on a budget  and b) undecisive about what we wanted to eat. The choices were outstanding: gourmet burgers, tasty thai dishes, korean bbq, beard papa's, japanese sushi/bentos, american comfort food, crepes...wow...it was like the United Nations of food here.
You totally have to try Tom's Cookies, wow, they were damn good. I ate like 8 of them in 2 days.
Since it was so near our hotel, this was a great place to go get some respite from shopping/sightseeing and honestly, all the food here was good. I sampled it all...Bristol Farms is a great place to grab snacks for the airplane ride, it was tres gourmet. I applaud this city for making even its smallest food experiences exceptionally fun, pretty, and tasty.
author: cindy w.

description: Ah, it's that time of the year again where the egg nog flows and the mistle toe hangs and the sweet smell of ginger bread fills the air and of course there is the dreaded holiday shopping.  Westfield however does not satisfy all my shopping needs as I thought it would.  The shops are not all that great because you can find flagship stores around the corner in Union Square.  The food emporium downstairs is absoluety amazing though.  I just wish that there were better stores.
author: Darren I.

description: This place is amazing. It's big and beautiful, and almost impossible to decide where to eat. I have only been there twice and the first time I decided it was just too much and went to eat at Panda, and the second time, I decided to splurge and headed to Coriander Gourmet Thai. The food. Was. FABULOUS. So good. Considering that it was the most expensive food court food I'd ever gotten, I was thoroughly satisfied. I only gave 4 stars because of the crowdedness, the trays (I agree!) and the prices.
author: Lindsey S.

description: CLASSY CLASSY CLASSY, thats all i have to say about thie food emporium.  I stepped in and in minutes i was battered by the many delightful smells of fine dining. lol okay maybe not fine dining but it is really really good. Theres ample room to sit and eat and the surplus of choices makes it an excellent place to dine anytime of the day. I also heard the gelato was amazing.
author: Kalvin C.

description: For the most part, this is a lovely place to dine in -- I just wish that there were different dining options. I feel that this could have been a fantastic way to show that San Francisco has a great history of culinary options, instead we get a slew of the same old restaurants, SF Soup Co., Bistro Burger, Asqew. They are good but with this fantastic new building, they decide to place restaurants that are already available out the front door of the mall within a few city blocks?
author: Taylor P.

description: Fanciest food court ever!  I'm sorry, "Food Emporium" (my bad).  Seriously, this is a very pleasant and convenient place to grab dinner before going to the movies upstairs.  Actually the Emporium is so clean and shiny, I would probably eat here even if I had no business in the mall.  I mean "Centre".
author: Anna S.

description: I am amazed at any food court that serves food on real plates and give you silverware - wowwww!  I love coming here during my lunch and shopping for the food - feel like a kid in a candy store.  Love Coriander Thai - amazing spicy food and Andale - large portions of Mexican food.  Also love Beard Papas - be careful when you eat the puffs  - you will get a beard of sugar - muahahhaa!  Skip the gelato place - does not taste like gelato, but pretty looking ice cream.
author: Ramoners D.

description: I really enjoy all the different options available, but seating is always a pain.  The only time I have been where I was able to find a place to sit easily was during breakfast time (around 10AM).  The Mexican place has a great breakfast burrito.
author: Jenna M.

description: I can't give a food court 5 stars, but so far everything I've tried here has been really good.  I work half a block away so it couldn't get much more convenient. While more expensive, it definitely beats the Lee's deli rut I was in for years. On my last visit I had a spinach salad from the burger place, it was huge and delicious and worth the money(although next time I'll get a burger from the burger place).
author: Jen S.

description:
i thought i loved the food emporium. 'bristol farms' is great for a quick mac 'n' cheese, 'out the door' has scrumptious chicken buns and 'peets coffee' will take care of your post-lunch food coma. 

but today, when a friend and sampled 'mr. hana' and sat at the south end of the emporium, we were surrounded by fruit flies! fruit flies take all the fun out of of an otherwise lovely lunch of  tender teriyaki chicken.
author: Kelly B.

description: Wow! This "food court" makes me want to move to San Francisco.  I got food from the Korean BBQ restaurant (ribs and spicy pork combo), and it was fantastic! Then I topped it off with a cream puff from Bearded Papa. It was almost as good as my grandmother used to make them back in Russia. I'm a fan!!!
author: Jason D.

description: Usually food courts in malls consist of McDonalds and Burger Kings. This place has a way better food selection. It's a pretty big place and lots of places to sit. I try and go eat here everytime i'm in SF. My cousin lives in SF so i want him to take me here. haha.
author: Garrett L.

description: I like Coriander Thai but the other stalls seem to serve Asian food too.  I think there's only a few vegetarian choices, like curry or side dishes.  Its always busy in here so there are long lines and noise.  My boyfriend gets too overwhelm to remember to order wine.  This is the reason I always get a hotel that has a microwave/refrigerator instead of going MacGyver with an ice bucket.
author: Ai M.

description: I am not a fan of mall food courts but this is by far the best food court in the U.S. that I have ever been too.  Nothing beats HK food courts.   But in terms of food quality and variety this place has it all.  You can pretty much get anything you want here.  If you can't find it all the food stalls then I am sure Bristol Farms will have the rest.  When people come up to visit and ask me were to eat in downtown I always tell them to come here because food in the downtown area sucks unless you want to spend some dough.  They think I am crazy.  But look at me!  Have you seen my big belly?
author: Fatty A.

description: Best food emporium on earth, hands down.  The vast selection is crazy.  Huge portions.  Minus one star for the insane crowds and noise.
author: Hannah G.

description: How difficult is it really to grill a chicken breast, throw on some sauce, put it on rice and add steamed/bland veggies..? I was disappointed at the lack of flavor the spicy chicken bowl had.  I guess that's what you get for trying to catch a quick meal at the mall.  However, there are a ton of other places in the emporium area to try that seem like they don't fit that stereotypical "food-court" stigma.  Definitely won't come back here.
author: Candice M.

description: My goodness! This place is so fancy for a food "emporium" in a mall! I LOVE IT! It has Beard Papa and some awesome iced tea place, I forget the name of. They also have Bristol Farms market here which has just about everything you could ever want!
author: Krystal N.

description: I love the variety at this place and it was really quick. The quality leaves something to be desired, but overall for a food court it's great.
author: T G.

description: I just enjjoy this food court so much! When my boyfriend and I take my son there for the 3D movies, my son loves trying the different foods. He seems to enjoy trying the sample foods and then asks to eat what he likes. He likes the Korean food for some reason. I have no idea how to prepare Korean food at home. This makes me laugh b ecause he will be cooking for us befoe long. Great Place!
author: Cathy S.

description: I'm also not sure what the big problem is with this place.  Plenty of places with food a step above typical mall food courts.  Definitely a decent haven if you need some place to catch your breath while your girl is on some shopping frenzy.
author: Shon R.

description: FINALLY!  A food court I enjoy and even look forward to going.  Today is my brother's birthday and he requested us to come here to celebrate.  Dang it, that sounds ghetto!  But I agree with him that this place is so much fun to go. We are especially fond of the court that serves tri-tip (i forgot the name).  Being from Hong Kong, we're used to food courts of this scale and have always been disappointed by most American mall food.  I'm so happy we finally have something like this to show my foreign friends.
author: R A.

description: Love the food emporium! Very good food court so far.. a little too trendy and modern for a food court, but, it's SF.. and it's in Westfield... so, I guess!! Quite a few of Asian cuisine =) and they are pretty good. Couldn't believe that I am excited about going to a food court now!!! They also have good dessert places such as Beard Papa.. yumm.. love their cream puffs, especially with the cookie crunch in it! Man, I'm addicted to the thing! and it's cheap too in here compares the one in Hawaii (honestly, only in SF I tried it and gosh.. oh, soo good!!) And, there are plenty of seat so you don't really have to wait for people to get up.
author: Daisy S.

description: SO MANY CHOICES! I love this food court. Everything is good.
author: Katherine C.

description:
not at all your typical run of the mill mall food court.  this one has a better selection and is far more upscale (and pricier) than any mall food court i've seen. you won't find the usual mcdonalds (ewww) and sbarro (kind of ewww too) here.  instead there's a branch of andale, bistro burger, a good pizza/pasta joint (forget the name) and buckhorn grill.

the variety makes it a really great place to meet friends for a meal - everyone can find something - yet it's not fast food.

the atmosphere can be a bit off putting at times, it's loud and crowded.  but trust me, you won't find a nicer food court in a mall.
author: Karen R.

description: Not bad for a food court in a mall. I liked the real silverware and place-settings, nice touch. Good place to grab lunch or an easy dinner before a movie. My fave: Coriander Gourmet Thai (mmm green curry chicken, so damn good!). Least favorite: Out the Door- I felt that they missed the mark on this, food was sub-par, especially considering the yummy goodness that is Slanted Door.
author: Dana K.

description: Some M-Fdays I am sooo over the workingbs that I need a respite from it all and go here for some foodspiration! Surprising that this foodcourt actually thought about OUT the doork, TEAz, BristolianFarming, Bearded papazpuffies...oh what a paradise the CITY can be...now what about that Trust Fund, sweet babykinz?
author: miriam b.

description: It's alright, but what is up with the seating, namely the microfiber booths?!  They are downright filthy!!!  Someone needs to wipe them down immediately.  I guess that's where all the families with kiddies sit.  Consider yourself warned.  Find an open table with the wooden seats if you can.
author: Poker B.

description:
Not a Food Court... but a Food EMPORIUM!

All the regulars are present; burger, Chinese, Japanese, Italian, Mexican, pretzel, etc... with a little extra Korean or Thai twist thrown in. Of course the names have all been changed so you can convince yourself you are eating something fresh and exciting.

Sure the food is a step above typical shopping mall fare, but the prices are a few steps higher. Good for a quick bite after a long afternoon of worshiping at the mighty temple of consumerism, but if it is dinnertime, do yourself a favor and try some of San Francisco's great restaurants. I hear Yelp has good recommendations...
author: M. W.

description: Ok, it's just a food court but it's not like your typical food court you'd find like at say, Serramonte or Stonestown. It's a little more 'upscale'. You just have to try it yourself and see how you like it but be warned; this place gets really crowded for some reason.
author: Conrad C.

description:
Okay. As far as food courts go, this is amazing. All you have to do is knock down some poor, starving picketers on the way to Bristol Farms to get yourself some ahi poke salad or a tri-tip sandwich.

Or, if you're not cruel and heartless like me, you can go to the Slanted Door take out and get yourself some really overpriced but yummy rolls and buns.

Or, if you're a cheap bastard like me, you'll just wait in line at Sorobol and eat some fast food Korean. Yum. Big portions + cheap = good date food right before the movies upstairs. Just remember: kim chee NOT = good date food for both its garlic effect and it's cabbage effect. (Unless you're already married, in which case, it's their own damned fault they married you, stinker.)
author: Tracy Y.

description: Nice shopping complex.  Can spend a whole day shopping, eating, reading at Border's, and catching a movie.
author: Dylan's Aunt E.

description:
I didn't expect a good Korean restaurant in a food court in a mall but Sorabol managed to do it.  It's cafeteria style and the line moves fast.  I had the calamari one time and the salted fish another time, and both were good and really spicy but high sodium city.  Large portions and also all the kim-chi that you want.  The price was above the usual food court cheapo but, hey, this isn't Panda Express.  And no tip is necessary.

So, if you're hungry and aren't ready to get on BART for the burbs--the Powell St. station is about 50 yards away--try this Korean place.
author: Murray S.

description: The roadhouse salad with tri-tip is amazing! My boyfriend and I split the salad and felt full and satisfied. The tri- tip was cooked perfectly and all of the veggies were fresh and crisp. Good times!
author: April H.

description: H.E.A.V.E.N.......I have been here so many times and its always been so much better.... or at least comparable.... to the pricey restaurants in S.F. The hi - lite? Mussels and clams over french fries. In a slightly creamy white wine sauce. For food court price. O....M....G. I've tried to re-create this food court wonder but it's never quite as jaw droppingly amazing. And all of the food vendors serve your food on chic white CHINA (... or great imitation) plates.. with REAL silverware..... and the booths are so comfy! Even a shorty like me can reach the table and still sit back in comfort. All of the food I have eaten has been FRESH and top quality. I just can't get over the fact that for the years and years I have been coming here... hung over from the crazy S.F. nights before or after a foot murdering day of shopping,  their food has been CONSISTENTLY amazing, satisfying, clean and fresh. If only you weren't a horrendous traffic drive away food court... if only...
author: Laura W.

description: This is not a food court, it's a food haven . . .a glutton's dream (like me!). Descending down the escalator into the sweet smelling lair, I have to keep myself from jumping and clapping my hands in glee. I don't go to the Westfield Shopping Center for Bloomingdale's or the Juicy store, I'm there for the food. I know it's not Gary Danko's or House of Prime Rib, but come on . . .it's a food court in a mall, and this one is at good as it gets. There are no Hot-Dogs-on-a-Stick, Mickey D's, or Sbarro's (if that's what you want and are complaining about here, then go to Hilltop Mall!) It does have a Sorabol however, which substantiates it as a real food court.  Everything else- the real plates and silverware, the larger-than-normal portions, the gourmet vendors, and the busboys that clean up after you- sets it apart. My mission is to eat at every spot here (except for the Mexican joint, but just because I don't like Mexican food). So far, I've only made it to Coriander Thai, Bristol Farms, and Teaz Me because I have a problem of always sticking to what I know and like. I have to get a little more adventurous if I want to reach my goal.
author: Alice P.

description: I have a built-in aversion to food courts (and shopping malls in general), but if you live in the city, sooner or later, you're going to find yourself in one.  And as food courts go, this is about as good as you're going to get.  Maybe things have changed & I've not been around to the food courts & shopping malls lately, but I can't remember the last time I ate at a food court off of REAL plates, knives & forks, and was able to get a REAL glass of wine (served in a REAL wine glass)!  As for the quality of food, I haven't eaten at EVERY place there, but what I HAVE tried was more than passable (and a lot better than I'd expect from the setting).  I went to Coriander Thai, and had the mixed vegetables & spicy green beans with fried rice (...and got a glass of white wine from another establishment, which was also better than I would have expected).  I must confess, my food was tasty.  Usually, in such a pedestrian, mainstream sort of setting, you would expect spicy dishes to be really toned-down for the masses, but my spicy green beans were PROPERLY SPICY and tasty, and my mixed vegetables were about as good as one can expect for such a boring dish.  And I would say that it was reasonably priced, as I got a literal MOUNTAIN of food for about $10.  Much more than I could finish.  Beyond the food that I had, the options in this food court all look like food I could actually CONSIDER EATING, unlike most food courts, which offer crap after crap after crap.  So, I won't be making any special trips TO this food court, as I will always prefer to be in a proper restaurant setting, NOT surrounded by all the mainstream, bridge & tunnel peeps & screaming kids, but if I find myself in the area again, I do know that I at least have decent options available to me when I get hungry.
author: Eric H.

description:
i love this food court.. or i guess they call it a food emporium, since it's so nice! the first time i came here was during a usual trip to SF for shopping, and i noticed that the westfield had been extended and the new section was finally open. ok, so the new side of the mall wasnt anything to be too surprised about since there are many malls that look about the same. However, the food court was definitely something I hadn't seen before. There are so many food options, and they are all differet from the usual food court choices. also, the food at many of the places are actually pretty damn good. the food comes in generous portions, and if you got me take out from this place , i would have never guessed it was from a mall food court/emporium. ive only tried the japanese and mexican options here. both were pretty good. but i love how the gelato/desserts and tea place looks.. also, they have a beard papa's! WOOHOO! (:

also, instead of waiting in line waiting to hear your number, each place gives you the flashing/vibrating pods that you get at restaurants. neat for a food court. also, there are people who bus your trays and items. good service. i just feel bad that the majority of the people working in this area are on the older side. 


if you're in SF and dont want to spend a lot of money at a restaurant, definitely visit this place. pretty cool.
author: Tiffany K.

description: I like this food court . It's very extensive and has a lot of options . The new side of the mall is the more expensive , more gorumet , and nicer part of the food court . The older side is the cheaper part of the food court and has more fast food . Overall , there's a little something for everyone . There's sandwiches , pizza , pasta , burgers , soup , cream puffs , Korean , Japanese , Thai , pretzels , etc.  I like the food court on the newer side of the mall more . I haven't seen a food court inside a mall in the bay area that has more gourmet foods like the one in this Westfield does . Most food courts only have cheap fast food . I haven't seen one with so many options either . I almost forget that I'm in the food court sometimes !! Why ? Because they have people cleaning up after you like in a restaurant . Also .. on the newer side of the mall ,  you can get your drink  or food " For here " and they will give you a glass cup and plate instead of a to-go cup or to-go box .
author: Eileen L.

description:
this is really is a food emporium...better then any mall food court i have ever been to

andale mexican restaurant- super good, great guac. fantastic chicken quesadilla's; good for sharing

a little bit expensive, but aren't all food courts/emporium's expensive...

author: Kate R.

description: Oh, Westfield food court, why do you keep pulling me back into your arms?  I wade through the swarm of people on Market and make way to your unusually heavy doors and to your escalators.  The molded plywood chairs are just high enough so that I can watch the people roll in and around between the tables and alleys of the food stalls.  There are mall workers and business travelers and tourists and local software hotshots and of course the gorgeous women refueling between bouts of shopping.  I am breathless and hungry for the seafood, the soup, the Thai fare, even Buckhorn who teases me with big chunks of beef but not that Askew place and indulge every so often, and once too many times, in a shouting match with that person who just cut me in line.  Don't get between me and the food court you animal!  Did I mention the folks at Peet's Coffee (OEM) are superb at pulling shots and making that Americano just right and hot?  Go forth; indulge your senses and feed.
author: Iqbal Y.

description: its a very cool place to shop and eat. my kids love the 4ht floor its very beautiful and fancy.    the food court is excellent except there is lots of table but not enough chair, it took us awhile to sit down and eat.
